events.event: Ahmad Shah Durrani defeats the Marathas in the Battle of Barari Ghat.
The Great Boston Fire of 1760 destroys 349 buildings.
French forces commence the siege of Quebec which is held by the British.
French forces besieging Quebec retreat after the Royal Navy arrives to relieve the British garrison.
Great Upheaval: New England planters arrive to claim land in Nova Scotia, Canada, taken from the Acadians.
French and Indian War: Robert Rogers and his Rangers surprise French held Fort Sainte Thérèse on the Richelieu River near Lake Champlain. The fort is raided and burned.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Landeshut: Austria defeats Prussia.
Anglo-Cherokee War: Cherokee warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Echoee near present-day Otto, North Carolina.
British forces defeat French forces in the last naval battle in New France.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Liegnitz: Frederick the Great's victory over the Austrians under Ernst Gideon von Laudon.
Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the U.S. Congress.
Brigham Young declares war on Timpanogos in the Battle at Fort Utah.
The Britannia Bridge across the Menai Strait between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales is opened.
Senator Daniel Webster gives his "Seventh of March" speech endorsing the Compromise of 1850 in order to prevent a possible civil war.
The Arana-Southern Treaty is ratified, ending "the existing differences" between Great Britain and Argentina.
Princess Louise of the Netherlands marries Crown Prince Karl of Sweden-Norway.
Autocephaly officially granted by the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople to the Church of Greece.
U.S. President Zachary Taylor dies after eating raw fruit and iced milk; he is succeeded in office by Vice President Millard Fillmore.
Persian prophet Báb is executed in Tabriz, Persia.
U.S. President Millard Fillmore is sworn in, a day after becoming president upon Zachary Taylor's death.
Establishment of the Colony of Vancouver Island.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: Battle of Chillianwala: British forces retreat from the Sikhs.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: The Siege of Multan ends after nine months when the last Sikh defenders of Multan, Punjab, surrender.
Elizabeth Blackwell is awarded her M.D. by the Geneva Medical College of Geneva, New York, becoming the United States' first female doctor.
University of Wisconsin-Madison's first class meets at Madison Female Academy.
The new Roman Republic is declared.

The delegation headed by Metropolitan bishop Andrei Șaguna hands out to the Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria the General Petition of Romanian leaders in Transylvania, Banat and Bukovina, which demands that the Romanian nation be recognized.
In New York City, James Knox Polk becomes the first serving President of the United States to have his photograph taken.
The Territory of Minnesota is created.

President-elect of the United States Zachary Taylor and Vice President-elect Millard Fillmore did not take their respective oaths of office (they did so the following day), leading to the erroneous theory that outgoing President pro tempore of the United States Senate David Rice Atchison had assumed the role of acting president for one day.
The first traveler's cheques, which could be used in 90 European cities, are issued by the London Credit Exchange Company.
Alexander Fordyce flees to France to avoid debt repayment, triggering the credit crisis of 1772 in the British Empire and the Dutch Republic.
The British schooner Gaspee is burned in Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island.
French explorer Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne and 25 of his men killed by Māori in New Zealand.
Gustav III of Sweden stages a coup d'état, in which he assumes power and enacts a new constitution that divides power between the Riksdag and the King.
King Gustav III completes his coup d'état by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden and installing himself as an enlightened despot.
The Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa is founded in San Luis Obispo, California.
Dissolution of Czechoslovakia: Czechoslovakia is divided into the Czech Republic and Slovak Republic.
Sri Lankan Civil War: The Sri Lanka Navy kill 35-100 civilians on the Jaffna Lagoon.
In Moscow, Russia, George H. W. Bush and Boris Yeltsin sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START).
The oil tanker MV Braer runs aground on the coast of the Shetland Islands, spilling 84,700 tons of crude oil.
Indian Border Security Force units kill 55 Kashmiri civilians in Sopore, Jammu and Kashmir, in revenge after militants ambushed a BSF patrol.
Four people are killed when Lufthansa CityLine Flight 5634 crashes on approach to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Roissy-en-France, France.
The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated with Jerry Rawlings as president.
Bosnian War: The Bosnian Army executes a surprise attack at the village of Kravica in Srebrenica.
Space Shuttle program: Endeavour heads for space for the third time as STS-54 launches from the Kennedy Space Center.
The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.
The United Principalities of Moldavia and Wallachia (later named Romania) is formed as a personal union under the rule of Domnitor Alexandru Ioan Cuza.
The Codex Sinaiticus is discovered in Egypt.

Alexandru Ioan Cuza, Prince of Moldavia, is also elected as prince of Wallachia, joining the two principalities as a personal union called the United Principalities, an autonomous region within the Ottoman Empire, which ushered in the birth of the modern Romanian state.
Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.
Cochinchina Campaign: The French Navy captures the Citadel of Saigon, a fortress manned by 1,000 Nguyễn dynasty soldiers, en route to conquering Saigon and other regions of southern Viet Nam.
Daniel E. Sickles, a New York Congressman, is acquitted of murder on grounds of temporary insanity.
The two-day Great Slave Auction, the largest such auction in United States history, begins.
The two-day Great Slave Auction, the largest such auction in United States history, concludes.
British and French engineers break ground for the Suez Canal.
The Cornwall Railway opens across the Royal Albert Bridge linking Devon and Cornwall in England.

Johannes Kepler confirms his previously rejected discovery of the third law of planetary motion (he first discovered it on March 8 but soon rejected the idea after some initial calculations were made).
The Second Defenestration of Prague precipitates the Thirty Years' War.
Joris Veseler prints the first Dutch newspaper Courante uyt Italien, Duytslandt, &c. in Amsterdam (approximate date).
Maurice, Prince of Orange disbands the waardgelders militia in Utrecht, a pivotal event in the Remonstrant/Counter-Remonstrant tensions.
The twelfth baktun in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar begins.
English adventurer, writer, and courtier Sir Walter Raleigh is beheaded for allegedly conspiring against James I of England.
The College of Arms is formally incorporated by Royal Charter signed by King Richard III of England.
William Caxton prints his translation of Aesop's Fables.
Portuguese sea captain Diogo Cão finds the mouth of the Congo River.

Battle of Lochmaben Fair: A 500-man raiding party led by Alexander Stewart, Duke of Albany and James Douglas, 9th Earl of Douglas are defeated by Scots forces loyal to Albany's brother James III of Scotland; Douglas is captured.
Pope Innocent VIII succeeds Pope Sixtus IV.
Pope Innocent VIII issues the Summis desiderantes affectibus, a papal bull that deputizes Heinrich Kramer and Jacob Sprenger as inquisitors to root out alleged witchcraft in Germany.
American Revolutionary War: Ratification Day, United States - Congress ratifies the Treaty of Paris with Great Britain.
The signing of the Treaty of Mangalore brings the Second Anglo-Mysore War to an end.
The Emerald Buddha is moved with great ceremony to its current location in Wat Phra Kaew, Thailand.

The Treaty of Paris, ratified by the United States Congress on January 14, 1784, is ratified by King George III of the Kingdom of Great Britain, ending the American Revolutionary War. Copies of the ratified documents are exchanged on May 12, 1784.
Élisabeth Thible becomes the first woman to fly in an untethered hot air balloon. Her flight covers four kilometres in 45 minutes, and reached 1,500 metres altitude (estimated).
Classical composer Luigi Boccherini receives a pay rise of 12000 reals from his employer, the Infante Luis, Count of Chinchón.
Western North Carolina (now eastern Tennessee) declares itself an independent state under the name of Franklin; it is not accepted into the United States, and only lasts for four years.
Russia founds a colony on Kodiak Island, Alaska.
Sixty-six people die in a nightclub fire in Bangkok, Thailand.
The first block of the blockchain of the decentralized payment system Bitcoin, called the Genesis block, is established by the creator of the system, Satoshi Nakamoto.
A 6.1-magnitude earthquake in northern Costa Rica kills 15 people and injures 32.

US Airways Flight 1549 ditches safely in the Hudson River after the plane collides with birds less than two minutes after take-off. This becomes known as "The Miracle on the Hudson" as all 155 people on board were rescued.
Barack Obama is inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States of America, becoming the first African-American President of the United States.
A protest movement in Iceland culminates as the 2009 Icelandic financial crisis protests start.
Israel withdraws from the Gaza Strip, officially ending a three-week war it had with Hamas. However, intermittent fire by both sides continues in the weeks to follow.
President Barack Obama signs an executive order to close the Guantanamo Bay detention camp; congressional opposition will prevent it being implemented.
Cyclone Klaus makes landfall near Bordeaux, France, causing 26 deaths as well as extensive disruptions to public transport and power supplies.
Rioting breaks out in Antananarivo, Madagascar, sparking a political crisis that will result in the replacement of President Marc Ravalomanana with Andry Rajoelina.
The First Peace of Thorn is signed in Thorn (Toruń), Monastic State of the Teutonic Knights (Prussia).
Following the successful campaigns during the Ottoman Interregnum, Musa Çelebi, one of the sons of Bayezid I, becomes Sultan of the Ottoman Empire with the support of Mircea I of Wallachia.
King Charles VI granted a monopoly for the ripening of Roquefort cheese to the people of Roquefort-sur-Soulzon as they had been doing for centuries.
Ming China's Admiral Zheng He returns to Nanjing after the third treasure voyage and presents the Sinhalese king, captured during the Ming-Kotte War, to the Yongle Emperor.
Battle of Harlaw, one of the bloodiest battles in Scotland, takes place.
The Treaty of Selymbria is concluded between the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Venice.
Ottoman-Hungarian wars: The Siege of Nándorfehérvár (Belgrade) begins.
A retrial verdict acquits Joan of Arc of heresy 25 years after her death.
Ottoman wars in Europe: Siege of Belgrade: John Hunyadi, Regent of the Kingdom of Hungary, defeats Mehmet II of the Ottoman Empire.
The University of Greifswald is established as the second oldest university in northern Europe.
Ulrich II, Count of Celje, last ruler of the County of Cilli, is assassinated in Belgrade.
The first of the two 1456 Central Italy earthquakes measuring Mw  7.2 causes extreme destruction and kills as many as 70,000 people.
Dreyfus affair: French army officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island.
The National Trust is founded in the United Kingdom.
First Italo-Ethiopian War: The war's opening battle, the Battle of Coatit, occurs; it is an Italian victory.
Fountains Valley, Pretoria, the oldest nature reserve in Africa, is proclaimed by President Paul Kruger.
William G. Morgan creates a game called Mintonette, which soon comes to be referred to as volleyball.
Revolution breaks out in Baire, a town near Santiago de Cuba, beginning the Cuban War of Independence; the war ends along with the Spanish-American War in 1898.
Auguste and Louis Lumière record their first footage using their newly patented cinematograph.
Before the Société pour L'Encouragement à l'Industrie, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière demonstrate movie film technology publicly for the first time.
The trial in the libel case brought by Oscar Wilde begins, eventually resulting in his imprisonment on charges of homosexuality.
In Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. the Supreme Court of the United States declares unapportioned income tax to be unconstitutional.
Thomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk is tried and found guilty of treason for his part in the Ridolfi plot to restore Catholicism in England.
In the Eighty Years' War, the Watergeuzen capture Brielle from the Seventeen Provinces, gaining the first foothold on land for what would become the Dutch Republic.
Nineteen Catholics suffer martyrdom for their beliefs in the Dutch town of Gorkum.
Marriage in Paris, France, of the Huguenot King Henry III of Navarre to Margaret of Valois, in a supposed attempt to reconcile Protestants and Catholics.
French Wars of Religion: Mob violence against thousands of Huguenots in Paris results in the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre.
Eighty Years' War: Three thousand Spanish soldiers wade through fifteen miles of water in one night to effect the relief of Goes.
Tycho Brahe observes the supernova SN 1572.
A launch of the communication satellite GSAT-14 aboard the GSLV MK.II D5 marks the first successful flight of an Indian cryogenic engine.
An explosion at a Mitsubishi Materials chemical plant in Yokkaichi, Japan, kills at least five people and injures 17 others.
A bomb attack on an army convoy in the city of Bannu kills at least 26 Pakistani soldiers and injures 38 others.
Rojava conflict: The Jazira Canton declares its autonomy from the Syrian Arab Republic.
Rojava conflict: The Kobanî Canton declares its autonomy from the Syrian Arab Republic.
Rojava conflict: The Afrin Canton declares its autonomy from the Syrian Arab Republic.
Two people are shot and killed and 29 students are taken hostage at a high school in Moscow, Russia.
Scientists announce that the Happisburgh footprints in Norfolk, England, date back to more than 800,000 years ago, making them the oldest known hominid footprints outside Africa.
A hotel fire in Medina, Saudi Arabia kills 15 Egyptian pilgrims with 130 others injured.
A military transport plane crashes in a mountainous area of Oum El Bouaghi Province in eastern Algeria, killing 77 people.
Kublai Khan becomes ruler of the Mongol Empire.
The Livonian Order suffers its greatest defeat in the 13th century in the Battle of Durbe against the Grand Duchy of Lithuania
The Mamluks defeat the Mongols at the Battle of Ain Jalut in Palestine, marking their first decisive defeat and the point of maximum expansion of the Mongol Empire.
The Sienese Ghibellines, supported by the forces of Manfred, King of Sicily, defeat the Florentine Guelphs at Montaperti.
The Great Prussian Uprising among the old Prussians begins against the Teutonic Knights.
Chartres Cathedral is dedicated in the presence of King Louis IX of France.
Sir Francis Drake with an English force captures and occupies the Spanish colonial port of Cartagena de Indias for two months, obtaining a ransom and booty.
Mary, Queen of Scots, recognizes Philip II of Spain as her heir and successor.
English colonists leave Roanoke Island, after failing to establish England's first permanent settlement in North America.
Anglo-Spanish War: A convoy of English ships from the Levant Company manage to repel a fleet of eleven Spanish and Maltese galleys off the Mediterranean island of Pantelleria.
The Battle of Zutphen is a Spanish victory over the English and Dutch.
Mary, Queen of Scots, goes on trial for conspiracy against Queen Elizabeth I of England.
Go-Yōzei becomes Emperor of Japan.
George Town, Penang, is made a city by a royal charter of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.
Lèse majesté in Thailand is strengthened to include "insult" and changed to a crime against national security, after the Thai criminal code of 1956 went into effect.: 6, 18
The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch.
In a speech given to the United States Congress, United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the establishment of what will later be called the Eisenhower Doctrine.
British Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden resigns from office following his failure to retake the Suez Canal from Egyptian sovereignty.
The African Convention is founded in Dakar, Senegal.
Kripalu Maharaj is named fifth Jagadguru (world teacher) after giving seven days of speeches before 500 Hindu scholars.
Israel withdraws from the Sinai Peninsula.
The New York City "Mad Bomber", George P. Metesky, is arrested in Waterbury, Connecticut and charged with planting more than 30 bombs.
American inventor Walter Frederick Morrison sells the rights to his flying disc to the Wham-O toy company, which later renames it the "Frisbee".
Euro currency is introduced in 11 member nations of the European Union (with the exception of the United Kingdom, Denmark, Greece and Sweden; Greece adopts the euro two years later).
The Mars Polar Lander is launched by NASA.
Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura is sworn in as governor of Minnesota, United States.
The Senate trial in the impeachment of U.S. President Bill Clinton begins.
British Aerospace agrees to acquire the defence subsidiary of the General Electric Company plc, forming BAE Systems in November 1999.
War on Drugs: In one of the largest drug busts in American history, the United States Coast Guard intercepts a ship with over 4,300 kilograms (9,500 lb) of cocaine on board.
Australian missionary Graham Staines and his two sons are burned alive by radical Hindus while sleeping in their car in Eastern India.
A 6.0 magnitude earthquake hits western Colombia killing at least 1,000.
Unarmed West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is shot 41 times by four plainclothes New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, inflaming race relations in the city.
Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the King of Jordan on the death of his father, King Hussein.
Wars of Scottish Independence end: By the Treaty of Edinburgh-Northampton, England recognises Scotland as an independent state.
Antipope Nicholas V, a claimant to the papacy, is consecrated in Rome by the Bishop of Venice.
William of Ockham, the Franciscan Minister-General Michael of Cesena, and two other Franciscan leaders secretly leave Avignon, fearing a death sentence from Pope John XXII.
Philip VI is crowned King of France.
The House of Gonzaga seizes power in the Duchy of Mantua, and will rule until 1708.
Battle of Cassel: French troops stop an uprising of Flemish farmers.

The original American Telephone & Telegraph Company is divested of its 22 Bell System companies as a result of the settlement of the 1974 United States Department of Justice antitrust suit against AT&T.
Brunei becomes independent of the United Kingdom.
Brunei becomes the sixth member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Holy See-United States relations: The United States and Holy See (Vatican City) re-establish full diplomatic relations after almost 117 years, overturning the United States Congress's 1867 ban on public funding for such a diplomatic envoy.
The Apple Macintosh, the first consumer computer to popularize the computer mouse and the graphical user interface, is introduced during a Super Bowl XVIII television commercial.
Apple Computer places the Macintosh personal computer on sale in the United States.
Tropical Storm Domoina makes landfall in southern Mozambique, eventually causing 214 deaths and some of the most severe flooding so far recorded in the region.
Doctor John Buster and a research team at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center in the United States announce history's first embryo transfer, from one woman to another resulting in a live birth.
Space Shuttle program: STS-41-B is launched using Space Shuttle Challenger.
Space Shuttle program: STS-41-B Mission: Astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart make the first untethered space walk using the Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU).
Greece is admitted into the European Community.
One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe, the "Yorkshire Ripper", is arrested in Sheffield, South Yorkshire.
A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence, France, claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive, gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments
Pope John Paul II receives a delegation from the Polish trade union Solidarity at the Vatican led by Lech Wałęsa.
President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law eight years and five months after declaring it.

Phil Smith and Phil Mayfield parachute off a Houston skyscraper, becoming the first two people to BASE jump from objects in all four categories: buildings, antennae, spans (bridges), and earth (cliffs).
Iran hostage crisis: United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.
Twenty minutes after Ronald Reagan is inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States of America, Iran releases 52 American hostages.
Production of the iconic DeLorean sports car begins in Dunmurry, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom.
The Dutch East India Company is established.
Cape Cod sighted by English navigator Bartholomew Gosnold.
An English naval force defeats a fleet of Spanish galleys, and captures a large Portuguese carrack at the Battle of Sesimbra Bay
The Dutch town of Grave held by the Spanish, capitulates to a besieging Dutch and English army under the command of Maurice of Orange.
Eighty Years' War and the Anglo-Spanish War: A fleet of Spanish galleys are defeated by English and Dutch galleons in the English Channel.
The Bodleian Library at the University of Oxford is opened to the public.

A surprise attack by forces under the command of Charles Emmanuel I, Duke of Savoy, and his brother-in-law, Philip III of Spain, is repelled by the citizens of Geneva. (Commemorated annually by the Fête de l'Escalade.)
India establishes its highest civilian awards, the Bharat Ratna and the Padma Vibhushan.
Georgetown-IBM experiment: The first public demonstration of a machine translation system is held in New York at the head office of IBM.
BOAC Flight 781, a de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1, explodes and falls into the Tyrrhenian Sea, killing 35 people.
The Hudson Motor Car Company merges with Nash-Kelvinator Corporation forming the American Motors Corporation.
In the United States, the National Negro Network is established with 40 charter member radio stations.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Nautilus, is launched in Groton, Connecticut by Mamie Eisenhower, the First Lady of the United States.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower warns against United States intervention in Vietnam.
Frank Selvy becomes the only NCAA Division I basketball player ever to score 100 points in a single game.
Canada and the United States agree to construct the Distant Early Warning Line, a system of radar stations in the far northern Arctic regions of Canada and Alaska.
The first Church of Scientology is established in Los Angeles.
Elizabeth I is crowned Queen of England in Westminster Abbey, London.
The second of two the treaties making up the Peace of Cateau-Cambrésis is signed, ending the Italian Wars.
John Knox returns from exile to Scotland to become the leader of the nascent Scottish Reformation.
Don Tristan de Luna y Arellano sails for Florida with party of 1,500, intending to settle on gulf coast (Vera Cruz, Mexico).
King Henry II of France is mortally wounded in a jousting match against Gabriel, comte de Montgomery.
Bartolomé Carranza, Spanish archbishop, is arrested for heresy.
Pope Pius IV is elected, four months after his predecessor's death.

The Netherlands, Great Britain, and France sign the Triple Alliance in an attempt to maintain the Treaty of Utrecht; Britain having signed a preliminary alliance with France on November 28 (November 17, 1716).
A sermon on "The Nature of the Kingdom of Christ" by Benjamin Hoadly, the Bishop of Bangor, preached in the presence of King George I of Great Britain, provokes the Bangorian Controversy.
Robert Walpole resigns from the British government, commencing the Whig Split which lasts until 1720.
The Premier Grand Lodge of England is founded in London, the first Masonic Grand Lodge in the world (now the United Grand Lodge of England).
King George I of Great Britain sails down the River Thames with a barge of 50 musicians, where George Frideric Handel's Water Music is premiered.
Austro-Turkish War of 1716-18: The month-long Siege of Belgrade ends with Prince Eugene of Savoy's Austrian troops capturing the city from the Ottoman Empire.
Spanish troops land on Sardinia.
An earthquake strikes Antigua Guatemala, destroying much of the city's architecture.
The First Peace of Thorn is signed in Thorn (Toruń), Monastic State of the Teutonic Knights (Prussia).
Following the successful campaigns during the Ottoman Interregnum, Musa Çelebi, one of the sons of Bayezid I, becomes Sultan of the Ottoman Empire with the support of Mircea I of Wallachia.
King Charles VI granted a monopoly for the ripening of Roquefort cheese to the people of Roquefort-sur-Soulzon as they had been doing for centuries.
Ming China's Admiral Zheng He returns to Nanjing after the third treasure voyage and presents the Sinhalese king, captured during the Ming-Kotte War, to the Yongle Emperor.
Battle of Harlaw, one of the bloodiest battles in Scotland, takes place.
The Treaty of Selymbria is concluded between the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Venice.
Popular Canadian American jockey George Woolf dies in a freak accident during a race; the annual George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award is created to honor him.
The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.

Andrei Zhdanov, Chairman of the Finnish Allied Commission, submitted to the Finnish War Criminal Court an interrogation report by General Erich Buschenhagen, a German prisoner of war, on the contacts between Finnish and German military personnel before the Continuation War and a copy of Hitler's Barbarossa plan.
The first General Assembly of the United Nations assembles in the Methodist Central Hall, Westminster. Fifty-one nations are represented.
The United States Army Signal Corps successfully conducts Project Diana, bouncing radio waves off the Moon and receiving the reflected signals.
Enver Hoxha, Secretary General of the Communist Party of Albania, declares the People's Republic of Albania with himself as head of state.
The UN Security Council holds its first session.
General Douglas MacArthur establishes the International Military Tribunal for the Far East in Tokyo to try Japanese war criminals.

In Iran, Qazi Muhammad declares the independent people's Republic of Mahabad at Chahar Cheragh Square in the Kurdish city of Mahabad; he becomes the new president and Haji Baba Sheikh becomes the prime minister.
Creation of the Central Intelligence Group, forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Greece is admitted into the European Community.
One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe, the "Yorkshire Ripper", is arrested in Sheffield, South Yorkshire.
A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence, France, claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive, gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments
Pope John Paul II receives a delegation from the Polish trade union Solidarity at the Vatican led by Lech Wałęsa.
President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law eight years and five months after declaring it.

Phil Smith and Phil Mayfield parachute off a Houston skyscraper, becoming the first two people to BASE jump from objects in all four categories: buildings, antennae, spans (bridges), and earth (cliffs).
Iran hostage crisis: United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.
Twenty minutes after Ronald Reagan is inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States of America, Iran releases 52 American hostages.
Production of the iconic DeLorean sports car begins in Dunmurry, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom.
The Republic of China is established.
The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Empire by royal charter.

The sixth All-Russian Conference of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Prague Party Conference) opens. In the course of the conference, Vladimir Lenin and his supporters break from the rest of the party to form the Bolshevik movement.
New Mexico is admitted to the Union as the 47th U.S. state.
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
The African National Congress is founded, under the name South African Native National Congress (SANNC).
Immigrant textile workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, go on strike when wages are reduced in response to a mandated shortening of the work week.
British polar explorer Captain Robert Falcon Scott reaches the South Pole, one month after Roald Amundsen.
The International Opium Convention is signed at The Hague.
The Xuantong Emperor, the last Emperor of China, abdicates.
A naval expedition led by Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa founds Nombre de Jesús, the first of two short-lived Spanish settlements in the Strait of Magellan.
Sir Walter Raleigh is granted a patent to colonize Virginia.
Santiago de Vera becomes sixth Governor-General of the Spanish colony of the Philippines.
Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe arrive at Roanoke Island
William I of Orange is assassinated in his home in Delft, Holland, by Balthasar Gérard.
San Lorenzo del Escorial Palace in Madrid is finished.
Fire destroys Jamestown, Virginia.
Emperor Susenyos I of Ethiopia surprises an Oromo army at Ebenat; his army reportedly kills 12,000 Oromo at the cost of 400 of his men.
Susenyos is formally crowned Emperor of Ethiopia.
In Ireland: O'Doherty's Rebellion is launched by the Burning of Derry.
A newly nationalized silver mine in Scotland at Hilderston, West Lothian is re-opened by Bevis Bulmer.
The Protestant Union, a coalition of Protestant German states, is founded to defend the rights, land and safety of each member against the Catholic Church and Catholic German states.
London: Virginia gets new charter, extending borders from "sea to sea".
Samuel de Champlain lands at Tadoussac, Quebec, in the course of his third voyage to New France, and begins erecting fortifications.
Québec City is founded by Samuel de Champlain.
The first official English representative to India lands in Surat.
Bouvet Island, the world's remotest island, is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier.
The Battle of Vasai commences as the Marathas move to invade Portuguese-occupied territory.
Battle of Karnal: The army of Iranian ruler Nader Shah defeats the forces of the Mughal emperor of India, Muhammad Shah.
Nader Shah occupies Delhi in India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne.
The Battle of Vasai concludes as the Marathas defeat the Portuguese army.
Stono Rebellion, the largest slave uprising in Britain's mainland North American colonies prior to the American Revolution, erupts near Charleston, South Carolina.
The Treaty of Belgrade is signed, whereby Austria cedes lands south of the Sava and Danube rivers to the Ottoman Empire.
The Treaty of Niš is signed by the Ottoman Empire and Russia ending the Russian-Turkish War.
The War of Jenkins' Ear begins with the first attack on La Guaira.
Start of the Battle of Porto Bello between British and Spanish forces during the War of Jenkins' Ear.
Final stage of the Mexican War of Independence from Spain with Plan of Iguala.
Greek War of Independence: Battle and fall of city of Kalamata.
Traditional date of the start of the Greek War of Independence. The war had actually begun on 23 February 1821 (Julian calendar).
Patriarch Gregory V of Constantinople is hanged by the Ottoman government from the main gate of the Patriarchate and his body is thrown into the Bosphorus.
Benderli Ali Pasha arrives in Constantinople as the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire; he remains in power for only nine days before being sent into exile.
Emperor Napoleon dies in exile on the island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean.
The first edition of The Manchester Guardian, now The Guardian, is published.
Greek War of Independence: The Greeks defeat the Turks at the Battle of Gravia Inn.
The first major battle of the Greek War of Independence against the Turks is fought in Valtetsi.
Establishment of the Peloponnesian Senate by the Greek rebels.
King Narai nominates Phetracha as regent, leading to the revolution of 1688 in which Phetracha becomes king of the Ayutthaya Kingdom.
The Immortal Seven issue the Invitation to William, which would culminate in the Glorious Revolution.
The city council of Amsterdam votes to support William of Orange's invasion of England, which became the Glorious Revolution.
William III of Orange sets out a second time from Hellevoetsluis in the Netherlands to seize the crowns of England, Scotland and Ireland from King James II of England during the Glorious Revolution.
William III of England lands with a Dutch fleet at Brixham.
Glorious Revolution: William of Orange captures Exeter.
Glorious Revolution: Williamite forces defeat Jacobites at Battle of Reading, forcing James II to flee England. (Date is Old Style; the date in the New Style modern calendar is 19 December.)
Glorious Revolution: James II of England, while trying to flee to France, throws the Great Seal of the Realm into the River Thames.
As part of the Glorious Revolution, King James II of England flees from England to Paris, France after being deposed in favor of his son-in-law and nephew, William of Orange and his daughter Mary.
The Democratic Party of the United States is organized.
Initial issue of the Cherokee Phoenix is the first periodical to use the Cherokee syllabary invented by Sequoyah.
René Caillié becomes the second non-Muslim to enter (and the first to return from) Timbuktu, following Major Gordon Laing.
U.S. President John Quincy Adams signs the Tariff of 1828 into law, protecting wool manufacturers in the United States.
Brazil and Argentina recognize the sovereignty of Uruguay in the Treaty of Montevideo
Morea expedition: The city of Patras, Greece, is liberated by the French expeditionary force.
Greek War of Independence: The French Morea expedition to recapture Morea (now the Peloponnese) ends when the last Ottoman forces depart the peninsula.
Greek War of Independence: The London Protocol entails the creation of an autonomous Greek state under Ottoman suzerainty, encompassing the Morea and the Cyclades.
Argentine general Juan Lavalle makes a coup against governor Manuel Dorrego, beginning the Decembrist revolution.
Vice President of the United States John C. Calhoun sparks the Nullification Crisis when he anonymously publishes the South Carolina Exposition and Protest, protesting the Tariff of 1828.
Cebu is established becoming the first Spanish settlement in the Philippines.
The Great Siege of Malta begins, in which Ottoman forces attempt and fail to conquer Malta.
Matsunaga Hisahide assassinates the 13th Ashikaga shōgun, Ashikaga Yoshiteru.
Dragut, commander of the Ottoman navy, dies during the Great Siege of Malta.
The widowed Mary, Queen of Scots marries Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, Duke of Albany, at Holyrood Palace, Edinburgh, Scotland.
Pedro Menéndez de Avilés sights land near St. Augustine, Florida and founds the oldest continuously occupied European-established city in the continental United States.
St. Augustine, Florida is founded by Spanish admiral and Florida's first governor, Pedro Menéndez de Avilés.
The Knights of Malta lift the Ottoman siege of Malta that began on May 18.
Ottoman forces retreat from Malta ending the Great Siege of Malta.
Ships belonging to the Matsura clan of Japan fail to capture the Portuguese trading carrack in the Battle of Fukuda Bay, the first recorded naval battle between Japan and the West.
Uruguayan War: The Siege of Paysandú ends as the Brazilians and Coloradans capture Paysandú, Uruguay.
American Civil War: Fort Fisher in North Carolina falls to the Union, thus cutting off the last major seaport of the Confederacy.
American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, abolishing slavery, and submits it to the states for ratification.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief of all Confederate armies.
President Abraham Lincoln signs the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

Delaware refuses to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Slavery was outlawed in the United States, including Delaware, when the Amendment was ratified by the requisite number of states on December 6, 1865. Delaware ratified the Thirteenth Amendment on February 12, 1901, which was the ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
American Civil War: Columbia, South Carolina, is burned as Confederate forces flee from advancing Union forces.
End of the Uruguayan War, with a peace agreement between President Tomás Villalba and rebel leader Venancio Flores, setting the scene for the destructive War of the Triple Alliance.
East Cape War: The Völkner Incident in New Zealand.
The third and final national flag of the Confederate States of America is adopted by the Confederate Congress.
Walter Raleigh is knighted, shortly after renaming North America region "Virginia", in honor of Elizabeth I, Queen of England, sometimes referred to as the "Virgin Queen".
The Olympic Theatre, designed by Andrea Palladio, is inaugurated in Vicenza.
The Treaty of Nemours abolishes tolerance to Protestants in France.
John Davis enters Cumberland Sound in search of the Northwest Passage.
The Treaty of Nonsuch signed by Elizabeth I of England and the Dutch Rebels.

Eighty Years' War: Siege of Antwerp: Antwerp is captured by Spanish forces under Alexander Farnese, Duke of Parma, who orders Protestants to leave the city and as a result over half of the 100,000 inhabitants flee to the northern provinces.
A first group of colonists sent by Sir Walter Raleigh under the charge of Ralph Lane lands in the New World to create Roanoke Colony on Roanoke Island, off the coast of present-day North Carolina.
War of the Austrian Succession: French forces defeat an Anglo-Dutch-Hanoverian army.
Battle of Hohenfriedberg: Frederick the Great's Prussian army decisively defeated an Austrian army under Prince Charles Alexander of Lorraine during the War of the Austrian Succession.
War of the Austrian Succession: New England colonial troops under the command of William Pepperrell capture the Fortress of Louisbourg in Louisbourg, New France (Old Style date).
A New England colonial army captures the French fortifications at Louisbourg (New Style).
French victory in the Battle of Melle allows them to capture Ghent in the days after.
The first recorded women's cricket match takes place near Guildford, England.
Prince Charles Edward Stuart raises his standard in Glenfinnan: The start of the Second Jacobite Rebellion, known as "the 45".
Ottoman-Persian War: In the Battle of Kars, the Ottoman army is routed by Persian forces led by Nader Shah.
A Hanoverian army is defeated, in ten minutes, by the Jacobite forces of Prince Charles Edward Stuart
Jacobite rising of 1745: Bonnie Prince Charles beats British government army in the Battle of Prestonpans.
Eritrea is consolidated into a colony by the Italian government.
The United Mine Workers of America is founded in Columbus, Ohio.
Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in 72 days.
The longest bridge in Great Britain, the Forth Bridge in Scotland, measuring 8,094 feet (2,467 m) long, is opened by the Duke of Rothesay, later King Edward VII.
Chancellor of the German Empire Otto von Bismarck is dismissed by Emperor Wilhelm II.
The Pan-American Union is founded by the First International Conference of American States in Washington, D.C.
The United States Census Bureau begins using Herman Hollerith's tabulating machine to count census returns.
Canada and Bermuda are linked by telegraph cable.
The U.S. Congress passes the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.
Ehud Olmert becomes acting Prime Minister of Israel after the incumbent, Ariel Sharon, suffers a second, apparently more serious stroke.
A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf is sworn in as Liberia's new president. She becomes Africa's first female elected head of state.
Evo Morales is inaugurated as President of Bolivia, becoming the country's first indigenous president.
Mexican professional wrestler Juana Barraza is arrested in connection with the serial killing of at least ten elderly women.
The roof of one of the buildings at the Katowice International Fair in Poland collapses due to the weight of snow, killing 65 and injuring more than 170 others.
Stephen Harper becomes Prime Minister of Canada.
The last Mobile army surgical hospital (MASH) is decommissioned by the United States Army.
A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.
A methane explosion in a coal mine near Nueva Rosita, Mexico, kills 65 miners.
In response to the execution of Nimr al-Nimr, Iran ends its diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia.
Joaquín Guzmán, widely regarded as the world's most powerful drug trafficker, is recaptured following his escape from a maximum security prison in Mexico.
West Air Sweden Flight 294 crashes near the Swedish reservoir of Akkajaure; both pilots, the only people on board, are killed.
Ten people are killed and 15 wounded in a bombing near the Blue Mosque in Istanbul.
The Kenyan Army suffers its worst defeat ever in a battle with Al-Shabaab Islamic insurgents in El-Adde, Somalia. An estimated 150 Kenyan soldiers are killed in the battle.
Thirty-three out of 126 freed hostages are injured and 23 killed in terrorist attacks in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso on a hotel and a nearby restaurant.
President Barack Obama announces the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action.
An earthquake of magnitude 6.6 strikes southern Taiwan, killing 117 people.
North Korea launches Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4 into outer space violating multiple UN treaties and prompting condemnation from around the world.
Two passenger trains collide in the German town of Bad Aibling in the state of Bavaria. Twelve people die and 85 others are injured.
Twenty-six people are killed and 63 wounded when a suicide bomber blows himself up at a police station in Damascus.
A hot air balloon crashes near Carterton, New Zealand, killing all 11 people on board.
A bombing at Jamrud in Pakistan, kills at least 30 people and injures 78 others.

Violent protests occur in Bucharest, Romania, as two-day-old demonstrations continue against President Traian Băsescu's economic austerity measures. Clashes are reported in numerous Romanian cities between protesters and law enforcement officers.
The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia sinks off the coast of Italy due to the captain Francesco Schettino's negligence and irresponsibility. There are 32 confirmed deaths.
The Mali War begins when Tuareg militias start fighting the Malian government for independence.
The Hong Kong-based file-sharing website Megaupload is shut down by the FBI.
Seventy-four people are killed and over 500 injured as a result of clashes between fans of Egyptian football teams Al Masry and Al Ahly in the city of Port Said.
The ferry MV Rabaul Queen sinks off the coast of Papua New Guinea near the Finschhafen District, with an estimated 146-165 dead.
A magnitude 6.7 earthquake hits the central Philippine island of Negros, leaving 112 people dead.
Slavery in Tunisia is abolished.
The Battle of Aliwal, India, is won by British troops commanded by Sir Harry Smith.
After the Milwaukee Bridge War, the United States towns of Juneautown and Kilbourntown unify to create the City of Milwaukee.
The first Mormon pioneers make their exodus from Nauvoo, Illinois, westward towards Salt Lake Valley.
First Anglo-Sikh War: Battle of Sobraon: British defeat Sikhs in the final battle of the war.

In Austin, Texas the newly formed Texas state government is officially installed. The Republic of Texas government officially transfers power to the State of Texas government following the annexation of Texas by the United States.
Polish insurgents lead an uprising in Kraków to incite a fight for national independence.
Thornton Affair: Open conflict begins over the disputed border of Texas, triggering the Mexican-American War.
The few remaining Mormons left in Nauvoo, Illinois, formally dedicate the Nauvoo Temple.
The Cambridge Chronicle, America's oldest surviving weekly newspaper, is published for the first time in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The first public school in the United States, Boston Latin School, is founded in Boston.
Thirty Years' War: The Peace of Prague is signed.
Guadeloupe becomes a French colony.
In the Eighty Years' War, the Spanish capture the strategic Dutch fortress of Schenkenschans.
Eighty Years' War: The Siege of Schenkenschans begins; Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange, begins the recapture of the strategically important fortress from the Spanish Army.
Roger Williams is banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony after religious and policy disagreements.
Dutch colonial forces on Taiwan launch a pacification campaign against native villages, resulting in Dutch control of the middle and south of the island.
King Henry VIII of England marries Anne of Cleves.
Waltham Abbey is surrendered to King Henry VIII of England; the last religious community to be closed during the Dissolution of the Monasteries.
Hernando de Alarcón sets sail on an expedition to the Gulf of California.
English King Henry VIII commands his 4th wife, Anne of Cleves, to leave the court.
King Henry VIII of England annuls his marriage to his fourth wife, Anne of Cleves.
Thomas Cromwell is executed at the order of Henry VIII of England on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.
Arequipa, Peru is founded.
The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) receives its charter from Pope Paul III.
Spanish conquistador Hernando de Soto's forces destroy the fortified town of Mabila in present-day Alabama, killing Tuskaloosa.
The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated in Paris.
The SS Gothenburg hits the Great Barrier Reef and sinks off the Australian east coast, killing approximately 100, including a number of high-profile civil servants and dignitaries.
Guangxu Emperor of Qing dynasty China begins his reign, under Empress Dowager Cixi's regency.
The first ever organized indoor game of ice hockey is played in Montreal, Quebec, Canada as recorded in the Montreal Gazette.
Archbishop of New York John McCloskey is named the first cardinal in the United States.
India: Arya Samaj is founded in Mumbai by Swami Dayananda Saraswati to propagate his goal of social reform.
Aristides wins the first Kentucky Derby with the jockey Oliver Lewis (2:37.75)
Signing of the Metre Convention by 17 nations leading to the establishment of the International System of Units.
The Herzegovinian rebellion against the Ottoman Empire begins.
The Herzegovina Uprising against Ottoman rule begins, which would last until 1878 and have far-reaching implications throughout the Balkans.
The world's first "Mercy" Hospital is founded in Pittsburgh, United States, by a group of Sisters of Mercy from Ireland; the name will go on to grace over 30 major hospitals throughout the world.
Samuel Colt obtains his first contract for the sale of revolver pistols to the United States government.
The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the Mexican-American War in California.
Westward expansion of the United States: John C. Frémont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
Yerba Buena, California is renamed San Francisco, California.
The first group of rescuers reaches the Donner Party.
Mexican-American War: The Battle of Buena Vista: Five thousand American troops defeat 15,000 Mexican troops.
Mexican-American War: Battle of Buena Vista: In Mexico, American troops under future president General Zachary Taylor defeat Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.
Mexican-American War: The first large-scale amphibious assault in U.S. history is launched in the Siege of Veracruz.
Mexican-American War: United States forces led by General Winfield Scott take Veracruz after a siege.
Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football (soccer) match.

The Harrisburg Seven: Rev. Philip Berrigan and five other activists are indicted on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry Kissinger and of plotting to blow up the heating tunnels of federal buildings in Washington, D.C.
The current Emley Moor transmitting station, the tallest free-standing structure in the United Kingdom, begins transmitting UHF broadcasts.
The Singapore Declaration, one of the two most important documents to the uncodified constitution of the Commonwealth of Nations, is issued.
Charles Manson and four "Family" members (three of them female) are found guilty of the 1969 Tate-LaBianca murders.
Idi Amin leads a coup deposing Milton Obote and becomes Uganda's president.
Apollo program: Apollo 14: Astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell, aboard a Saturn V, lift off for a mission to the Fra Mauro Highlands on the Moon.
The Winter Soldier Investigation, organized by the Vietnam Veterans Against the War to publicize war crimes and atrocities by Americans and allies in Vietnam, begins in Detroit.
Idi Amin replaces President Milton Obote as leader of Uganda.
First Battle of Seattle: Marines from the USS Decatur drive off American Indian attackers after all-day battle with settlers.
Queen Victoria issues a Warrant under the Royal sign-manual that establishes the Victoria Cross to recognise acts of valour by British military personnel during the Crimean War.
The Kingdom of Awadh is annexed by the British East India Company and Wajid Ali Shah, the king of Awadh, is deposed.
The United States Republican Party opens its first national convention in Pittsburgh.[citation needed]
The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.
Second Battle of Rivas: Juan Santamaría burns down the hostel where William Walker's filibusters are holed up.
Australian labour movement: Stonemasons and building workers on building sites around Melbourne march from the University of Melbourne to Parliament House to achieve an eight-hour day.
Lawrence, Kansas is captured and burned by pro-slavery forces.

Congressman Preston Brooks of South Carolina severely beats Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts with a cane in the hall of the United States Senate for a speech Sumner had made regarding  Southerners and slavery.
John Brown and his men kill five slavery supporters at Pottawatomie Creek, Kansas.
The Kingdom of Great Britain signs preliminary articles of peace with the Kingdom of France, setting the stage for the official end of hostilities in the American Revolutionary War later that year.
Spain-United States relations are first established.
In Calabria, a sequence of strong earthquakes begins.
American Revolutionary War: French and Spanish forces lift the Great Siege of Gibraltar.
In an emotional speech in Newburgh, New York, George Washington asks his officers not to support the Newburgh Conspiracy. The plea is successful and the threatened coup d'état never takes place.

Three-Fifths Compromise: The first instance of black slaves in the United States of America being counted as three fifths of persons (for the purpose of taxation), in a resolution of the Congress of the Confederation. This was later adopted in the 1787 Constitution.
First United Empire Loyalists reach Parrtown (later called Saint John, New Brunswick), Canada, after leaving the United States.
A Great Jubilee Day held at North Stratford, Connecticut, celebrates the end of fighting in the American Revolution.
The Montgolfier brothers publicly demonstrate their montgolfière (hot air balloon).
Laki, a volcano in Iceland, begins an eight-month eruption which kills over 9,000 people and starts a seven-year famine.
The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States Civil Service, is enacted by Congress.
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires, built by Thomas Edison, begins service at Roselle, New Jersey.
Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an anti-trust law.
The Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property is signed.
Buffalo Bill's 1st Buffalo Bill's Wild West opens in Omaha, Nebraska.
Krakatoa begins to erupt; the volcano explodes three months later, killing more than 36,000 people.
The Brooklyn Bridge in New York City is opened to traffic after 14 years of construction.
Alexander III is crowned Tsar of Russia.
In New York City, a stampede on the recently opened Brooklyn Bridge killed twelve people.
The first regularly scheduled Orient Express departs Paris.
The first Polish stamp is issued, replacing the Russian stamps previously in use.
Abraham Lincoln makes a speech at Cooper Union in the city of New York that is largely responsible for his election to the Presidency.
Parma, Tuscany, Modena and Romagna vote in referendums to join the Kingdom of Sardinia.
The First Taranaki War begins in Taranaki, New Zealand, a major phase of the New Zealand Wars.
Sakuradamon Incident: Japanese Chief Minister (Tairō) Ii Naosuke is assassinated by rōnin samurai outside the Sakurada Gate of Edo Castle.
First Taranaki War: The Battle of Waireka begins.
The first successful United States Pony Express run from St. Joseph, Missouri, to Sacramento, California, begins.
The Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, later renamed Community of Christ, is organized by Joseph Smith III and others at Amboy, Illinois.
On his phonautograph machine, Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville makes the oldest known recording of an audible human voice.
1860 United States presidential election: Abraham Lincoln wins the Republican Party presidential nomination over William H. Seward, who later becomes the United States Secretary of State.
The Gateway Bridge, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia is officially opened.
Space Shuttle program: NASA Administrator Bill Nelson lifts off from Kennedy Space Center aboard Columbia on mission STS-61-C as a payload specialist.
A month-long violent struggle begins in Aden, South Yemen between supporters of Ali Nasir Muhammad and Abdul Fattah Ismail, resulting in thousands of casualties.

The first IBM PC computer virus is released into the wild. A boot sector virus dubbed (c)Brain, it was created by the Farooq Alvi Brothers in Lahore, Pakistan, reportedly to deter unauthorized copying of the software they had written.
In the United States, Martin Luther King Jr. Day is celebrated as a federal holiday for the first time.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducts its first members: Little Richard, Chuck Berry, James Brown, Ray Charles, Sam Cooke, Fats Domino, The Everly Brothers, Buddy Holly, Jerry Lee Lewis and Elvis Presley.
The Voyager 2 space probe makes its closest approach to Uranus.
The National Resistance Movement topples the government of Tito Okello in Uganda.
The Ugandan government of Tito Okello is overthrown by the National Resistance Army, led by Yoweri Museveni.
Space Shuttle program: STS-51-L mission: Space Shuttle Challenger disintegrates after liftoff, killing all seven astronauts on board.
Downtown Disney opens to the public as part of the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
An earthquake hits El Salvador, killing more than 800.
Wikipedia, a free wiki content encyclopedia, goes online.
Second Congo War: Congolese President Laurent-Désiré Kabila is assassinated by one of his own bodyguards in Kinshasa.
US President Bill Clinton awards former President Theodore Roosevelt a posthumous Medal of Honor for his service in the Spanish-American War.
President of the Philippines Joseph Estrada is ousted in a nonviolent four-day revolution, and is succeeded by Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

Five people attempt to set themselves on fire in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, an act that many people later claim is staged by the Communist Party of China to frame Falun Gong and thus escalate their persecution.
The 7.7 Mw Gujarat earthquake shakes Western India, leaving 13,805-20,023 dead and about 166,800 injured.
Thousands of student protesters in Indonesia storm parliament and demand that President Abdurrahman Wahid resign due to alleged involvement in corruption scandals.
In the Netherlands, a Scottish court convicts Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi and acquits another Libyan citizen for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
Treaty of Roskilde: After a devastating defeat in the Northern Wars (1655-1661), Frederick III, the King of Denmark-Norway is forced to give up nearly half his territory to Sweden.
Battle of Samugarh: decisive battle in the struggle for the throne during the Mughal war of succession (1658-1659).
Pope Alexander VII appoints François de Laval vicar apostolic in New France.
Spanish forces fail to retake Jamaica at the Battle of Rio Nuevo during the Anglo-Spanish War.
Aurangzeb is proclaimed Mughal emperor of India.
The death of Oliver Cromwell; Richard Cromwell becomes Lord Protector of England.
The Battle of Vilanova is fought between Portugal and Spain during the Portuguese Restoration War.
Second Northern War: Naval forces of the Dutch Republic defeat the Swedes in the Battle of the Sound.
A naval expedition led by Pedro Sarmiento de Gamboa founds Nombre de Jesús, the first of two short-lived Spanish settlements in the Strait of Magellan.
Sir Walter Raleigh is granted a patent to colonize Virginia.
Santiago de Vera becomes sixth Governor-General of the Spanish colony of the Philippines.
Philip Amadas and Arthur Barlowe arrive at Roanoke Island
William I of Orange is assassinated in his home in Delft, Holland, by Balthasar Gérard.
San Lorenzo del Escorial Palace in Madrid is finished.
Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile.

Charles Martin Hall produced the first samples of aluminium from the electrolysis of aluminium oxide, after several years of intensive work. He was assisted in this project by his older sister, Julia Brainerd Hall.
Geronimo, Apache warrior, surrenders to the U.S. Army, ending the main phase of the Apache Wars.
John Pemberton brews the first batch of Coca-Cola in a backyard in Atlanta.
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.

Rallies are held throughout the United States demanding the eight-hour work day, culminating in the Haymarket affair in Chicago, in commemoration of which May 1 is celebrated as International Workers' Day in many countries.
Haymarket affair: A bomb is thrown at policemen trying to break up a labor rally in Chicago, United States, killing eight and wounding 60. The police fire into the crowd.
Pharmacist John Pemberton first sells a carbonated beverage named "Coca-Cola" as a patent medicine.
The pharmacist John Pemberton places his first advertisement for Coca-Cola, which appeared in The Atlanta Journal.
Topsy, an elephant, is electrocuted by the owners of Luna Park, Coney Island. The Edison film company records the film Electrocuting an Elephant of Topsy's death.
Hallam Tennyson, 2nd Baron Tennyson, son of the poet Alfred Tennyson, becomes the second Governor-General of Australia.
El Yunque National Forest in Puerto Rico becomes part of the United States National Forest System as the Luquillo Forest Reserve.
Anton Bruckner's 9th Symphony receives its first performance in Vienna, Austria.
The United States Department of Commerce and Labor is established (later split into the Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor).
Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
In New York City the Martha Washington Hotel opens, becoming the first hotel exclusively for women.
Pelican Island National Wildlife Refuge, the first national wildlife refuge in the US, is established by President Theodore Roosevelt.
The Kishinev pogrom in Kishinev (Bessarabia) begins, forcing tens of thousands of Jews to later seek refuge in Palestine and the Western world.
Atlético Madrid Association football club is founded
Ellis Island begins processing immigrants into the United States.
James Naismith publishes the rules of basketball.
St. Petersburg, Florida is incorporated.
The General Electric Company is formed.
In San Francisco, John Muir organizes the Sierra Club.
The Chicago "L" elevated rail system begins operation.
Homer Plessy is arrested for refusing to leave his seat in the "whites-only" car of a train; he lost the resulting court case, Plessy v. Ferguson.
The Limelight Department, one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
The Homestead Strike begins near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Western Samoa changes the International Date Line, causing Monday (July 4) to occur twice, resulting in a year with 367 days.
English King Charles II declares war on the Netherlands marking the start of the Second Anglo-Dutch War.
The first joint Secretary of the Royal Society, Henry Oldenburg, publishes the first issue of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, the world's longest-running scientific journal.
James Stuart, Duke of York (later to become King James II of England), defeats the Dutch fleet off the coast of Lowestoft.
Thomas Willett is appointed the first mayor of New York City.
Battle of Montes Claros: Portugal definitively secured independence from Spain in the last battle of the Portuguese Restoration War.
Portuguese forces defeat the Kingdom of Kongo and decapitate King António I of Kongo, also known as Nvita a Nkanga.
The London Gazette, the oldest surviving journal, is first published.
The Royal Netherlands Marine Corps is founded by Michiel de Ruyter.
The ARPANET officially changes to using TCP/IP, the Internet Protocol, effectively creating the Internet.
Turkish Airlines Flight 158 crashes at Ankara Esenboğa Airport in Ankara, Turkey, killing 47 and injuring 20.
The International Olympic Committee restores Jim Thorpe's Olympic medals to his family.
Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie is arrested in Bolivia.
The Apple Lisa, the first commercial personal computer from Apple Inc. to have a graphical user interface and a computer mouse, is announced.
The pilot shaft of the Seikan Tunnel, the world's longest sub-aqueous tunnel (53.85 km) between the Japanese islands of Honshū and Hokkaidō, breaks through.

Singapore cable car crash: Panamanian-registered oil rig, Eniwetok, strikes the cables of the Singapore Cable Car system linking the mainland and Sentosa Island, causing two cabins to fall into the water and killing seven people and leaving thirteen others trapped for hours.

The Melbourne dust storm hits Australia's second largest city. The result of the worst drought on record and a day of severe weather conditions, a 320 metres (1,050 ft) deep dust cloud envelops the city, turning day to night.
Irish race horse Shergar is stolen by gunmen.

One hundred women protest in Lahore, Pakistan against military dictator Zia-ul-Haq's proposed Law of Evidence. The women were tear-gassed, baton-charged and thrown into lock-up. The women were successful in repealing the law.

In a vote of confidence, General Pervez Musharraf wins 658 out of 1,170 votes in the Electoral College of Pakistan, and according to Article 41(8) of the Constitution of Pakistan, is "deemed to be elected" to the office of President until October 2007.
Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2, collecting samples that are returned to Earth.
Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea, resulting in 148 deaths, making it one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Egyptian history.
Spirit, a NASA Mars rover, lands successfully on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
Mikheil Saakashvili is elected President of Georgia following the November 2003 Rose Revolution.
The RMS Queen Mary 2, then the largest ocean liner ever built, is christened by her namesake's granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

An inflatable boat carrying illegal Albanian emigrants stalls near the Karaburun Peninsula en route to Brindisi, Italy; exposure to the elements kills 28. This is the second deadliest marine disaster in Albanian history.
The world's largest ocean liner, RMS Queen Mary 2, makes its maiden voyage.
The national flag of the Republic of Georgia, the so-called "five cross flag", is restored to official use after a hiatus of some 500 years.
NASA's MER-A (the Mars Rover Spirit) ceases communication with mission control. The problem lies in the management of its flash memory and is fixed remotely from Earth on February 6.
French and Indian War: The Treaty of Paris ends the war and France cedes Quebec to Great Britain.
Berbice slave uprising in Guyana: The first major slave revolt in South America.
Pontiac's War begins with Pontiac's attempt to seize Fort Detroit from the British.
Pontiac's Rebellion: At what is now Mackinaw City, Michigan, Chippewas capture Fort Michilimackinac by diverting the garrison's attention with a game of lacrosse, then chasing a ball into the fort.
Odawa Chief Pontiac's forces defeat British troops at the Battle of Bloody Run during Pontiac's War.
Pontiac's War: Battle of Bushy Run: British forces led by Henry Bouquet defeat Chief Pontiac's Indians at Bushy Run.
Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow.
Seneca warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Devil's Hole during Pontiac's War.
King George III issues the Royal Proclamation of 1763, closing Indigenous lands in North America north and west of the Alleghenies to white settlements.
Dedication of the Touro Synagogue, in Newport, Rhode Island, the first synagogue in what will become the United States.
The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuse to swear loyalty to Galba. They rebel and proclaim Vitellius as emperor.
The Roman legions on the Rhine refuse to declare their allegiance to Galba, instead proclaiming their legate, Aulus Vitellius, as emperor.
Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is appointed by Galba as deputy Roman Emperor.
Otho seizes power in Rome, proclaiming himself Emperor of Rome, beginning a reign of only three months.
Vitellius, commander of the Rhine armies, defeats Emperor Otho in the Battle of Bedriacum to take power over Rome.
Defeated by Vitellius' troops at Bedriacum, Otho commits suicide.
Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his Roman legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as Emperor.
Batavian rebellion: The Batavians in Germania Inferior (Netherlands) revolt under the leadership of Gaius Julius Civilis.
In the Second Battle of Bedriacum, troops loyal to Vespasian defeat those of Emperor Vitellius.
Antonius Primus enters Rome to claim the title of Emperor for Nero's former general Vespasian.
World War I: The Battle of Rafa is fought near the Egyptian border with Palestine.
The Kingsland munitions factory explosion occurs as a result of sabotage.
The United States pays Denmark $25 million for the Virgin Islands.
Silvertown explosion: A blast at a munitions factory in London kills 73 and injures over 400. The resulting fire causes over £2,000,000 worth of damage.
American entry into World War I: President Woodrow Wilson of the still-neutral United States calls for "peace without victory" in Europe.
Sinking of the SS Laurentic after hitting two German mines off the coast of Northern Ireland.
World War I: Kaiser Wilhelm II orders the resumption of unrestricted submarine warfare.
World War I: The American entry into World War I begins when diplomatic relations with Germany are severed due to its unrestricted submarine warfare.
The current constitution of Mexico is adopted, establishing a federal republic with powers separated into independent executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
The Congress of the United States passes the Immigration Act of 1917 over President Woodrow Wilson's veto.
The Montreal Protocol comes into force, stopping the use of chemicals contributing to ozone depletion.
Second Gulf of Sidra incident: A pair of Libyan MiG-23 "Floggers" are shot down by a pair of US Navy F-14 Tomcats during an air-to-air confrontation.
Satwant Singh and Kehar Singh are sentenced to death for conspiracy in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi; the two men are executed the same day.
Kegworth air disaster: British Midland Flight 92, a Boeing 737-400, crashes into the M1 motorway, killing 47 of the 126 people on board.
Notorious serial killer Ted Bundy, with over 30 known victims, is executed by the electric chair at the Florida State Prison.
Cold War: Hungary establishes diplomatic relations with South Korea, making it the first Eastern Bloc nation to do so.
The American embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan is closed.
Soviet-Afghan War: The last Soviet armoured column leaves Kabul.
After a stroke two weeks previously, South African President P. W. Botha resigns as leader of the National Party, but stays on as president for six more months.
A military coup overthrows Alfredo Stroessner, dictator of Paraguay since 1954.
Alfred Vail and colleagues demonstrate a telegraph system using dots and dashes (this is the forerunner of Morse code).
Weenen massacre: Hundreds of Voortrekkers along the Blaukraans River, Natal are killed by Zulus.
The French Army captures Veracruz in the Pastry War.
Nicaragua declares independence from the Central American Federation.
Myall Creek massacre: Twenty-eight Aboriginal Australians are murdered.
Coronation of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom.
The Iowa Territory is organized.

Ralph Waldo Emerson delivers the Divinity School Address at Harvard Divinity School, discounting Biblical miracles and declaring Jesus a great man, but not God. The Protestant community reacts with outrage.
The Wilkes Expedition, which would explore the Puget Sound and Antarctica, weighs anchor at Hampton Roads.
Saint Andrew's Scots School, the oldest school of British origin in South America, is established.
Massacre of Glencoe: Almost 80 Macdonalds at Glen Coe, Scotland are killed early in the morning for not promptly pledging allegiance to the new king, William of Orange.
Sarah Good, Sarah Osborne and Tituba are brought before local magistrates in Salem Village, Massachusetts, beginning what would become known as the Salem witch trials.
Bridget Bishop is the first person to be tried for witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts; she was found guilty and later hanged.
Port Royal, Jamaica, is hit by a catastrophic earthquake; in just three minutes, 1,600 people are killed and 3,000 are seriously injured.
Salem witch trials: Bridget Bishop is hanged at Gallows Hill near Salem, Massachusetts, for "certaine Detestable Arts called Witchcraft and Sorceries".
Salem witch trials: In Salem, Province of Massachusetts Bay, five people, one woman and four men, including a clergyman, are executed after being convicted of witchcraft.
The last hanging of those convicted of witchcraft in the Salem witch trials; others are all eventually released.
The Salem witch trials are ended by a letter from Province of Massachusetts Bay Governor William Phips.
Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football (soccer) match.

The Harrisburg Seven: Rev. Philip Berrigan and five other activists are indicted on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry Kissinger and of plotting to blow up the heating tunnels of federal buildings in Washington, D.C.
The current Emley Moor transmitting station, the tallest free-standing structure in the United Kingdom, begins transmitting UHF broadcasts.
The Singapore Declaration, one of the two most important documents to the uncodified constitution of the Commonwealth of Nations, is issued.
Charles Manson and four "Family" members (three of them female) are found guilty of the 1969 Tate-LaBianca murders.
Idi Amin leads a coup deposing Milton Obote and becomes Uganda's president.
Apollo program: Apollo 14: Astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell, aboard a Saturn V, lift off for a mission to the Fra Mauro Highlands on the Moon.
The Winter Soldier Investigation, organized by the Vietnam Veterans Against the War to publicize war crimes and atrocities by Americans and allies in Vietnam, begins in Detroit.
Idi Amin replaces President Milton Obote as leader of Uganda.
Following a currency reform, Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
A massive ice storm hits eastern Canada and the northeastern United States, continuing through January 10 and causing widespread destruction.
Over 100 people are killed in the Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria.
Nineteen European nations agree to forbid human cloning.
Alfredo Ormando sets himself on fire in St. Peter's Square, protesting against homophobia.
Clinton-Lewinsky scandal: Matt Drudge breaks the story of the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky affair on his Drudge Report website.
Space Shuttle program: space shuttle Endeavour launches on STS-89 to dock with the Russian space station Mir.
Netscape announces Mozilla, with the intention to release Communicator code as open source.
During a historic visit to Cuba, Pope John Paul II demands political reforms and the release of political prisoners while condemning US attempts to isolate the country.
A suicide attack by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam on Sri Lanka's Temple of the Tooth kills eight and injures 25 others.

In the Sverdlovsk air disaster, all 19 of those on board are killed, including almost the entire national ice hockey team (VVS Moscow) of the Soviet Air Force - 11 players, as well as a team doctor and a masseur.
The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China. The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the UK in response.
British submarine HMS Truculent collides with an oil tanker in the Thames Estuary, killing 64 men.
Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
The Great Brink's Robbery: Eleven thieves steal more than $2 million from an armored car company's offices in Boston.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 79 relating to arms control is adopted.
American lawyer and government official Alger Hiss is convicted of perjury.
The Knesset resolves that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.
The Constitution of India comes into force, forming a republic. Rajendra Prasad is sworn in as the first President of India. Observed as Republic Day in India.
President Truman orders the development of thermonuclear weapons.
French troops, led by Francis, Duke of Guise, take Calais, the last continental possession of England.
The city of Pori (Swedish: Björneborg) was founded by Duke John on the shores of the Gulf of Bothnia.
Mary, Queen of Scots, marries the Dauphin of France, François, at Notre Dame de Paris.
Battle of Gravelines: In France, Spanish forces led by Count Lamoral of Egmont defeat the French forces of Marshal Paul de Thermes at Gravelines.
Poczta Polska, the Polish postal service, is founded.
Elizabethan era begins: Queen Mary I of England dies and is succeeded by her half-sister Elizabeth I of England.

The Convention Parliament convenes to determine whether James II and VII, the last Roman Catholic monarch of England, Ireland and Scotland, had vacated the thrones of England and Ireland when he fled to France in 1688.
The Convention Parliament declares that the flight to France in 1688 by James II, the last Roman Catholic British monarch, constitutes an abdication.
William and Mary are proclaimed co-rulers of England.
James II of England landed at Kinsale, starting the Williamite War in Ireland.
William III and Mary II are crowned as joint sovereigns of Great Britain.
Bostonians rise up in rebellion against Sir Edmund Andros.
Deposed monarch James II of England lays siege to Derry.
The English Parliament passes the Act of Toleration protecting dissenting Protestants but excluding Roman Catholics.
Glorious Revolution: The Battle of Killiecrankie is a victory for the Jacobites.
Beaver Wars: Fifteen hundred Iroquois attack Lachine in New France.
Ronald Reagan, past movie actor and future President of the United States, is sworn in as Governor of California.
Cultural Revolution: The Shanghai People's Commune is established following the seizure of power from local city officials by revolutionaries.
Vietnam War: United States Marine Corps and ARVN troops launch "Operation Deckhouse Five" in the Mekong River delta.
Dr. James Bedford becomes the first person to be cryonically preserved with intent of future resuscitation.
Counterculture of the 1960s: The Human Be-In takes place in San Francisco, California's Golden Gate Park, launching the Summer of Love.
The first Super Bowl is played in Los Angeles. The Green Bay Packers defeat the Kansas City Chiefs 35-10.
Albert DeSalvo, the "Boston Strangler", is convicted of numerous crimes and is sentenced to life imprisonment.
Between dozens and hundreds of anti-Somocista demonstrators are killed by the Nicaraguan National Guard in Managua.
Diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Ivory Coast are established.

Milton Keynes (England) is founded as a new town by Order in Council, with a planning brief to become a city of 250,000 people. Its initial designated area enclosed three existing towns and twenty-one villages. The area to be developed was largely farmland, with evidence of continuous settlement dating back to the Bronze Age.
Uruguayan War: The Siege of Paysandú ends as the Brazilians and Coloradans capture Paysandú, Uruguay.
American Civil War: Fort Fisher in North Carolina falls to the Union, thus cutting off the last major seaport of the Confederacy.
American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, abolishing slavery, and submits it to the states for ratification.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief of all Confederate armies.
President Abraham Lincoln signs the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

Delaware refuses to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Slavery was outlawed in the United States, including Delaware, when the Amendment was ratified by the requisite number of states on December 6, 1865. Delaware ratified the Thirteenth Amendment on February 12, 1901, which was the ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
American Civil War: Columbia, South Carolina, is burned as Confederate forces flee from advancing Union forces.
