In Florida, Hernando de Soto lands at Tampa Bay with 600 soldiers with the goal of finding gold.
Hernando de Soto claims Florida for Spain.
Council of Trent: Pope Paul III sends out letters to his bishops, delaying the Council due to war and the difficulty bishops had traveling to Venice.
Spain's DeSoto expedition takes over the Apalachee capital of Anhaica for their winter quarters.
King Henry VIII of England marries Anne of Cleves.
Waltham Abbey is surrendered to King Henry VIII of England; the last religious community to be closed during the Dissolution of the Monasteries.
Hernando de Alarcón sets sail on an expedition to the Gulf of California.
English King Henry VIII commands his 4th wife, Anne of Cleves, to leave the court.
King Henry VIII of England annuls his marriage to his fourth wife, Anne of Cleves.
Thomas Cromwell is executed at the order of Henry VIII of England on charges of treason. Henry marries his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, on the same day.
Arequipa, Peru is founded.
The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) receives its charter from Pope Paul III.
Spanish conquistador Hernando de Soto's forces destroy the fortified town of Mabila in present-day Alabama, killing Tuskaloosa.
Japanese invasion of Korea: Approximately 3,000 Joseon defenders led by general Kwon Yul successfully repel more than 30,000 Japanese forces in the Siege of Haengju.
The Dutch city of Coevorden held by the Spanish, falls to a Dutch and English force.
London playwright Thomas Kyd is arrested and tortured by the Privy Council for libel.
Playwright Thomas Kyd's accusations of heresy lead to an arrest warrant for Christopher Marlowe.
Battle of Sisak: Allied Christian troops defeat the Ottomans.
The Dutch city of Geertruidenberg held by the Spanish, capitulates to a besieging Dutch and English army led by Maurice of Nassau.
Henry IV of France publicly converts from Protestantism to Roman Catholicism.
Pierre Barrière failed an attempt to assassinate Henry IV of France.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
Napoleon Bonaparte captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of Mount Tabor: Napoleon drives Ottoman Turks across the River Jordan near Acre.

Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: The Battle of Seringapatam: The siege of Seringapatam ends when the city is invaded and Tipu Sultan killed by the besieging British army, under the command of General George Harris.
War of the Second Coalition: Austrian forces defeat the French at Winterthur, Switzerland.
Action of 18 June 1799: A frigate squadron under Rear-admiral Jean-Baptiste Perrée is captured by the British fleet under Lord Keith.
Ranjit Singh conquers Lahore and becomes Maharaja of the Punjab (Sikh Empire).
The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.
The first American college football bowl game, the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford, is held in Pasadena, California.
The Carnegie Institution of Washington is founded in Washington, D.C. with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
The first Anglo-Japanese Alliance is signed in London.
Second Boer War: Australian soldiers Harry "Breaker" Morant and Peter Handcock are executed in Pretoria after being convicted of war crimes.
Second Boer War: Boers, led by Koos de la Rey, inflict the biggest defeat upon the British since the beginning of the war, at Tweebosch.
Macario Sakay issues Presidential Order No. 1 of his Tagalog Republic.
Dmitry Sipyagin, Minister of Interior of the Russian Empire, is assassinated in the Marie Palace, Saint Petersburg.
"Electric Theatre", the first full-time movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles.

A stand box collapses at Ibrox Park (now Ibrox Stadium) in Glasgow, Scotland, which led to the deaths of 25 and injuries to more than 500 supporters during an international association football match between Scotland and England.
The 7.5 Mw  Guatemala earthquake shakes Guatemala with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), killing between 800 and 2,000.
Second Anglo-Dutch War: Rear Admiral Robert Holmes leads a raid on the Dutch island of Terschelling, destroying 150 merchant ships, an act later known as "Holmes's Bonfire".
The Great Fire of London breaks out and burns for three days, destroying 10,000 buildings, including Old St Paul's Cathedral.
The Royal Exchange burns down in the Great Fire of London.
In London, England, the most destructive damage from the Great Fire occurs.
Great Fire of London ends: Ten thousand buildings, including Old St Paul's Cathedral, are destroyed, but only six people are known to have died.
At least 3,000 men of the Royal Scots Army led by Tam Dalyell of the Binns defeat about 900 Covenanter insurgents led by James Wallace of Auchens in the Battle of Rullion Green.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
Napoleon Bonaparte captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of Mount Tabor: Napoleon drives Ottoman Turks across the River Jordan near Acre.

Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: The Battle of Seringapatam: The siege of Seringapatam ends when the city is invaded and Tipu Sultan killed by the besieging British army, under the command of General George Harris.
War of the Second Coalition: Austrian forces defeat the French at Winterthur, Switzerland.
Action of 18 June 1799: A frigate squadron under Rear-admiral Jean-Baptiste Perrée is captured by the British fleet under Lord Keith.
Ranjit Singh conquers Lahore and becomes Maharaja of the Punjab (Sikh Empire).
The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.
The World Trade Organization comes into being.
The Draupner wave in the North Sea in Norway is detected, confirming the existence of freak waves.
Austria, Finland and Sweden join the EU.
A chemical fire in an apartment complex in Manila, Philippines, leads to the discovery of plans for Project Bojinka, a mass-terrorist attack.
An avalanche hits the Icelandic village Súðavík, destroying 25 homes and burying 26 people, 14 of whom died.
The 6.9 Mw  Great Hanshin earthquake shakes the southern Hyōgo Prefecture with a maximum Shindo of VII, leaving 5,502-6,434 people dead, and 251,301-310,000 displaced.
After being struck by lightning the crew of Bristow Helicopters Flight 56C are forced to ditch. All 18 aboard are later rescued.
Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Beit Lid suicide bombing: In central Israel, near Netanya, two Gazans blow themselves up at a military transit point, killing 19 Israeli soldiers.
The Norwegian rocket incident: Russia almost launches a nuclear attack after it mistakes Black Brant XII, a Norwegian research rocket, for a US Trident missile.
Hydroxycarbamide becomes the first approved preventive treatment for sickle cell disease.
The Black Friday bushfires burn 20,000 square kilometers of land in Australia, claiming the lives of 71 people.
Norway claims Queen Maud Land in Antarctica.
The deadliest earthquake in Chilean history strikes Chillán, killing approximately 28,000 people.
Spanish Civil War: Catalonia Offensive: Troops loyal to nationalist General Francisco Franco and aided by Italy take Barcelona.
First flight of the Lockheed P-38 Lightning.
Generalísimo Francisco Franco becomes the 68th "Caudillo de España", or Leader of Spain.
Spanish Civil War: The Nationalists conclude their conquest of Catalonia and seal the border with France.

As part of British air raid precautions, the first of 2.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}1⁄2 million Anderson shelters is constructed in a garden in Islington, north London.

United States labor law: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in NLRB v. Fansteel Metallurgical Corp. that the National Labor Relations Board has no authority to force an employer to rehire workers who engage in sit-down strikes.
An Imperial Japanese Army ammunition dump explodes at Hirakata, Osaka, Japan, killing 94.
Nigeria becomes British protectorate with Frederick Lugard as high commissioner.
American statesman and diplomat John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote trade with China.
Chicago Canal opens.
Irish nationalist leader John Edward Redmond calls for revolt against British rule.
Second Boer War: Having already besieged the fortress at Ladysmith, Boer forces attack it, but are driven back by British defenders.
President William McKinley  places Alaska under military rule.
To combat Czech nationalism, Emperor Franz Joseph decrees German will be language of the Austro-Hungarian Armed Forces.
Giacomo Puccini's Tosca opens in Rome.
The United States Senate accepts the Anglo-German treaty of 1899 in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the Samoan islands.
Second Boer War: The Battle of Spion Kop between the forces of the South African Republic and the Orange Free State and British forces ends in a British defeat.
The United States Senate allows the Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
In Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, the first Groundhog Day is observed.
The Dawes Act authorizes the President of the United States to survey Native American tribal land and divide it into individual allotments.
The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000.
Argonia, Kansas elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.
On Easter Sunday, Pope Leo XIII authorizes the establishment of the Catholic University of America.
A week after being arrested by the Prussian Secret Police, French police inspector Guillaume Schnaebelé is released on order of William I, German Emperor, defusing a possible war.
Herman Hollerith applies for US patent #395,781 for the 'Art of Compiling Statistics', which was his punched card calculator.
The Reinsurance Treaty between Germany and Russia is signed.
The Rocky Mountains Park Act becomes law in Canada creating the nation's first national park, Banff National Park.

American Revolutionary War: One thousand five hundred soldiers of the 6th Pennsylvania Regiment under General Anthony Wayne's command rebel against the Continental Army's winter camp in Morristown, New Jersey in the Pennsylvania Line Mutiny of 1781.
American Revolutionary War: Richmond, Virginia, is burned by British naval forces led by Benedict Arnold.
In the Battle of Jersey, the British defeat the last attempt by France to invade Jersey in the Channel Islands.

American Revolutionary War: Battle of Cowpens: Continental troops under Brigadier General Daniel Morgan defeat British forces under Lieutenant Colonel Banastre Tarleton at the battle in South Carolina.
American Revolutionary War: British forces seize the Dutch-owned Caribbean island Sint Eustatius.
Fourth Anglo-Dutch War: Captain Thomas Shirley opens his expedition against Dutch colonial outposts on the Gold Coast of Africa (present-day Ghana).
The Articles of Confederation goes into effect in the United States.
William Herschel discovers Uranus.
American Revolutionary War: British and French ships clash in the Battle of Fort Royal off the coast of Martinique.
Jack Jouett begins his midnight ride to warn Thomas Jefferson and the Virginia legislature of an impending raid by Banastre Tarleton.
Arauco War: The first Parliament of Quillín is celebrated, putting a temporary hold on hostilities between Mapuches and Spanish in Chile.
Guaraní forces living in the Jesuit reductions defeat bandeirantes loyal to the Portuguese Empire at the Battle of Mbororé in present-day Panambí, Argentina.
The Treaty of London between England and Scotland, ending the Bishops' Wars, is signed.
The Merchant Royal, carrying a treasure of over 100,000 pounds of gold (worth over £1 billion today), is lost at sea off Land's End.
Irish Catholic gentry from Ulster attempt to seize control of Dublin Castle, the seat of English rule in Ireland, so as to force concessions.
Felim O'Neill of Kinard, the leader of the Irish Rebellion, issues his Proclamation of Dungannon, justifying the uprising and declaring continued loyalty to King Charles I of England.
The U.S. Congress approves Indian Territory (in what is present-day Oklahoma), clearing the way for forced relocation of the Eastern Indians on the "Trail of Tears".
The Ohio Legislature authorizes the construction of the Ohio and Erie Canal and the Miami and Erie Canal.

After no candidate receives a majority of electoral votes in the US presidential election of 1824, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams as sixth President of the United States in a contingent election.
The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the United States government by the Treaty of Indian Springs, and migrate west.
Roberto Cofresí, one of the last successful Caribbean pirates, is defeated in combat and captured by authorities.
General Lafayette, a French officer in the American Revolutionary War, speaks at what would become Lafayette Square, Buffalo, during his visit to the United States.
The first cornerstone is laid for Fort Hamilton in New York City.
The Bolivian Declaration of Independence is proclaimed.
The Thirty-Three Orientals declare the independence of Uruguay from Brazil.
The world's first public railway to use steam locomotives, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, is ceremonially opened.
Uruguayan War: The Siege of Paysandú ends as the Brazilians and Coloradans capture Paysandú, Uruguay.
American Civil War: Fort Fisher in North Carolina falls to the Union, thus cutting off the last major seaport of the Confederacy.
American Civil War: The United States Congress passes the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, abolishing slavery, and submits it to the states for ratification.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief of all Confederate armies.
President Abraham Lincoln signs the Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

Delaware refuses to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Slavery was outlawed in the United States, including Delaware, when the Amendment was ratified by the requisite number of states on December 6, 1865. Delaware ratified the Thirteenth Amendment on February 12, 1901, which was the ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
American Civil War: Columbia, South Carolina, is burned as Confederate forces flee from advancing Union forces.
End of the Uruguayan War, with a peace agreement between President Tomás Villalba and rebel leader Venancio Flores, setting the scene for the destructive War of the Triple Alliance.
East Cape War: The Völkner Incident in New Zealand.
The third and final national flag of the Confederate States of America is adopted by the Confederate Congress.
The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
The Great Blizzard of 1888 begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400 people.
Start of the Anglo-Tibetan War of 1888.
The premiere of the very first Romani language operetta is staged in Moscow, Russia.
In England, The Football League, the world's oldest professional association football league, meets for the first time.
Jack the Ripper: The first of 11 unsolved brutal murders of women committed in or near the impoverished Whitechapel district in the East End of London, occurs.
In Southeast Asia, the North Borneo Chartered Company's territories become the British protectorate of North Borneo.
With the passage of the Lei Áurea ("Golden Law"), Empire of Brazil abolishes slavery.
Nikola Tesla delivers a lecture describing the equipment which will allow efficient generation and use of alternating currents to transmit electric power over long distances.
The Rio de la Plata earthquake takes place.
Johann Wolfgang von Goethe's Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy receives its premiere performance.
In the London Protocol, the three protecting powers (United Kingdom, France and Russia) establish the borders of Greece.
The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829, allowing Catholics to serve in Parliament.
The Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829 gives Roman Catholics in the United Kingdom the right to vote and to sit in Parliament.
Charles Fremantle arrives in HMS Challenger off the coast of modern-day Western Australia prior to declaring the Swan River Colony for the British Empire.
After anchoring nearby, Captain Charles Fremantle of HMS Challenger, declares the Swan River Colony in Australia.
Accordion patent granted to Cyrill Demian in Vienna, Austrian Empire.
HMS Pickle captures the armed slave ship Voladora off the coast of Cuba.
The first Boat Race between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge takes place on the Thames in London.
In the United States, William Austin Burt patents the typographer, a precursor to the typewriter.
British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
Napoleon Bonaparte captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
French Revolutionary Wars: The Battle of Mount Tabor: Napoleon drives Ottoman Turks across the River Jordan near Acre.

Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: The Battle of Seringapatam: The siege of Seringapatam ends when the city is invaded and Tipu Sultan killed by the besieging British army, under the command of General George Harris.
War of the Second Coalition: Austrian forces defeat the French at Winterthur, Switzerland.
Action of 18 June 1799: A frigate squadron under Rear-admiral Jean-Baptiste Perrée is captured by the British fleet under Lord Keith.
Ranjit Singh conquers Lahore and becomes Maharaja of the Punjab (Sikh Empire).
The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign.
American Civil War: The Emancipation Proclamation takes effect in Confederate territory.
The New Apostolic Church, a Christian and chiliastic church, is established in Hamburg, Germany.
American Civil War: Second Battle of Springfield.
The Metropolitan Railway, the world's oldest underground railway, opens between Paddington and Farringdon, marking the beginning of the London Underground.
American Civil War: Battle of Arkansas Post: General John McClernand and Admiral David Dixon Porter capture the Arkansas River for the Union.
American Civil War: CSS Alabama encounters and sinks the USS Hatteras off Galveston Lighthouse in Texas.
The January Uprising breaks out in Poland, Lithuania and Belarus. The aim of the national movement is to regain Polish-Lithuanian-Ruthenian Commonwealth from occupation by Russia.
American Civil War: General Ambrose Burnside is relieved of command of the Army of the Potomac after the disastrous Fredericksburg campaign. He is replaced by Joseph Hooker.
American Civil War: Governor of Massachusetts John Albion Andrew receives permission from the Secretary of War to raise a militia organization for men of African descent.

The Bear River Massacre: A detachment of California Volunteers led by Colonel Patrick Edward Connor engage the Shoshone at Bear River, Washington Territory, killing hundreds of men, women and children.
Miyamoto Musashi defeats Sasaki Kojirō at Funajima island.
Famous sword duel between Miyamoto Musashi and Sasaki Kojiro on the shores of Ganryū Island. Kojiro dies at the end.
The trial of the Pendle witches, one of England's most famous witch trials, begins at Lancaster Assizes.
The "Samlesbury witches", three women from the Lancashire village of Samlesbury, England, are put on trial, accused of practicing witchcraft, one of the most famous witch trials in British history.
During the Time of Troubles, Polish troops are expelled from Moscow's Kitay-gorod by Russian troops under the command of Dmitry Pozharsky (22 October O.S.).
The Battle of Swally takes place, which loosens the Portuguese Empire's hold on India.
George Washington delivers the first State of the Union address in New York City.
The first United States census is authorized.
France is divided into 83 départements, cutting across the former provinces in an attempt to dislodge regional loyalties based on ownership of land by the nobility.
Rhode Island becomes the last of North America's original Thirteen Colonies to ratify the Constitution and become one of the United States.
Manuel Quimper explores the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
The United States enacts its first copyright statute, the Copyright Act of 1790.
The Swedish Navy captures one third of the Russian Baltic fleet.
The Civil Constitution of the Clergy is passed in France by the National Constituent Assembly.
Inaugural Fête de la Fédération is held to celebrate the unity of the French people and the national reconciliation.
The District of Columbia is established as the capital of the United States after signature of the Residence Act.
The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, opens as the world's first university museum.
William Penn signs a friendship treaty with Lenni Lenape Indians in Pennsylvania.
Manchu Qing dynasty naval forces under traitorous commander Shi Lang defeat the Kingdom of Tungning in the Battle of Penghu near the Pescadores Islands.
Battle of Vienna: Coalition forces, including the famous winged Hussars, led by Polish King John III Sobieski lift the siege laid by Ottoman forces.
Austro-Ottoman War: Battle of Vienna: Several European armies join forces to defeat the Ottoman Empire.
Antonie van Leeuwenhoek writes a letter to the Royal Society describing "animalcules", later known as protozoa.
Qing dynasty naval commander Shi Lang receives the surrender of the Tungning kingdom on Taiwan after the Battle of Penghu.
Immigrant families found Germantown, Pennsylvania in the first major immigration of German people to America.
The British Crown colony of New York is subdivided into 12 counties.
Willem Barents and Jacob van Heemskerk discover Bear Island.
The Dutch explorer Willem Barentsz discovers the Arctic archipelago of Spitsbergen.
Anglo-Spanish War: English and Dutch troops sack the Spanish city of Cádiz before leaving the next day.
The Spanish ship San Felipe runs aground on the coast of Japan and its cargo is confiscated by local authorities
The second Spanish armada sets sail to strike against England, but is smashed by storms off Cape Finisterre forcing a retreat to port.
The Cudgel War begins in Finland (at the time part of Sweden), when peasants rebel against the imposition of taxes by the nobility.
The first traveler's cheques, which could be used in 90 European cities, are issued by the London Credit Exchange Company.
Alexander Fordyce flees to France to avoid debt repayment, triggering the credit crisis of 1772 in the British Empire and the Dutch Republic.
The British schooner Gaspee is burned in Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island.
French explorer Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne and 25 of his men killed by Māori in New Zealand.
Gustav III of Sweden stages a coup d'état, in which he assumes power and enacts a new constitution that divides power between the Riksdag and the King.
King Gustav III completes his coup d'état by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden and installing himself as an enlightened despot.
The Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa is founded in San Luis Obispo, California.
The Night of the Big Wind, the most damaging storm in 300 years, sweeps across Ireland, damaging or destroying more than 20% of the houses in Dublin.
The French Academy of Sciences announces the Daguerreotype photography process.
The British East India Company captures Aden.
In the Battle of Yungay, Chile defeats an alliance between Peru and Bolivia.
A massive earthquake destroys the former capital Inwa of the Konbaung dynasty, present-day Myanmar.
The first Henley Royal Regatta is held.
The Treaty of London establishes Belgium as a kingdom and guarantees its neutrality.
In Humen, China, Lin Tse-hsü destroys 1.2 million kilograms of opium confiscated from British merchants, providing Britain with a casus belli to open hostilities, resulting in the First Opium War.
Henley Royal Regatta: the village of Henley-on-Thames, on the River Thames in Oxfordshire, stages its first regatta.

In the Kingdom of Hawaii, Kamehameha III issues the edict of toleration which gives Roman Catholics the freedom to worship in the Hawaiian Islands. The Hawaii Catholic Church and the Cathedral of Our Lady of Peace are established as a result.
Austria, the United Kingdom, and France form a secret defensive alliance against Prussia and Russia.
War of 1812: Battle of New Orleans: Andrew Jackson leads American forces in victory over the British.
War of 1812: British troops capture Fort Peter in St. Marys, Georgia, the only battle of the war to take place in the state.
War of 1812: American frigate USS President, commanded by Commodore Stephen Decatur, is captured by a squadron of four British frigates.
Napoleon Bonaparte escapes from exile on the island of Elba.
Napoleon returns to France from his banishment on Elba.
Signing of the Kandyan Convention treaty by British invaders and the leaders of the Kingdom of Kandy.
Francis Ronalds describes the first battery-operated clock in the Philosophical Magazine.
Prince Willem proclaims himself King of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands, the first constitutional monarch in the Netherlands.
After escaping from Elba, Napoleon enters Paris with a regular army of 140,000 and a volunteer force of around 200,000, beginning his "Hundred Days" rule.
The world's first "Mercy" Hospital is founded in Pittsburgh, United States, by a group of Sisters of Mercy from Ireland; the name will go on to grace over 30 major hospitals throughout the world.
Samuel Colt obtains his first contract for the sale of revolver pistols to the United States government.
The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the Mexican-American War in California.
Westward expansion of the United States: John C. Frémont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
Yerba Buena, California is renamed San Francisco, California.
The first group of rescuers reaches the Donner Party.
Mexican-American War: The Battle of Buena Vista: Five thousand American troops defeat 15,000 Mexican troops.
Mexican-American War: Battle of Buena Vista: In Mexico, American troops under future president General Zachary Taylor defeat Mexican General Antonio López de Santa Anna.
Mexican-American War: The first large-scale amphibious assault in U.S. history is launched in the Siege of Veracruz.
Mexican-American War: United States forces led by General Winfield Scott take Veracruz after a siege.
Point No Point Treaty is signed in Washington Territory.
A locomotive on the Panama Canal Railway runs from the Atlantic Ocean to the Pacific Ocean for the first time.
Kassa Hailu is crowned Tewodros II, Emperor of Ethiopia.
Michigan State University is established.
Texas is linked by telegraph to the rest of the United States, with the completion of a connection between New Orleans and Marshall, Texas.
Alexander II becomes Tsar of Russia.
Origins of the American Civil War: "Border Ruffians" from Missouri invade Kansas and force election of a pro-slavery legislature.
American adventurer William Walker departs from San Francisco with about 60 men to conquer Nicaragua.
The American adventurer William Walker conquers Nicaragua.
Major Henry C. Wayne departs New York aboard the USS Supply to procure camels to establish the U.S. Camel Corps.
The United States Post Office Department issues a set of 12 stamps commemorating the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth.
Hattie Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate.
Finland and the Soviet Union sign a non-aggression treaty.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese National Revolutionary Army begins the defense of Harbin.
Japanese forces attack Shanghai.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Harbin, Manchuria, falls to Japan.
Prohibition law is abolished in Finland after a national referendum, where 70% voted for a repeal of the law.

The Empire of Japan creates the independent state of Manzhouguo (the obsolete Chinese name for Manchuria) free from the Republic of China and installed former Chinese Emperor Aisin Gioro Puyi as Chief Executive of the State.

Hitler, having been stateless for seven years, obtains German citizenship when he is appointed a Brunswick state official by Dietrich Klagges, a fellow Nazi. As a result, Hitler is able to run for Reichspräsident in the 1932 election.
Aviator Charles Lindbergh's 20-month-old son Charles Jr is kidnapped from his home in East Amwell, New Jersey. His body would not be found until May 12.
Alexander Dubček comes to power in Czechoslovakia, effectively beginning the "Prague Spring".
Surveyor Program: Surveyor 7, the last spacecraft in the Surveyor series, lifts off from launch complex 36A, Cape Canaveral.
Johnny Cash performs live at Folsom State Prison.
Vietnam War: Battle of Khe Sanh: One of the most publicized and controversial battles of the war begins.
A B-52 bomber crashes near Thule Air Base, contaminating the area after its nuclear payload ruptures. One of the four bombs remains unaccounted for after the cleanup operation is complete.
Apollo 5 lifts off carrying the first Lunar module into space.
Operation Igloo White, a US electronic surveillance system to stop communist infiltration into South Vietnam begins installation.
USS Pueblo (AGER-2) is attacked and seized by the Korean People's Navy.
Vietnam War: The 1st Australian Task Force launches Operation Coburg against the North Vietnamese Army and Viet Cong during wider fighting around Long Bình and Biên Hòa.
Vietnam War: Tet Offensive launch by forces of the Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army against South Vietnam, the United States, and their allies.
The first American commercial bank, the Bank of North America, opens.
Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris addresses the U.S. Congress to recommend establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
Spanish defeat British forces and capture Menorca.
American Revolutionary War: The House of Commons of Great Britain votes against further war in America.

Gnadenhutten massacre: Ninety-six Native Americans in Gnadenhutten, Ohio, who had converted to Christianity, are killed by Pennsylvania militiamen in retaliation for raids carried out by other Indian tribes.
The Second Rockingham ministry assumes office in Great Britain and begins negotiations to end the American War of Independence.
King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke (Rama I) of Siam (modern day Thailand) establishes the Chakri dynasty.
John Adams secures Dutch recognition of the United States as an independent government. The house which he had purchased in The Hague becomes the first American embassy.
The city of Rattanakosin, now known internationally as Bangkok, is founded on the eastern bank of the Chao Phraya River by King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
Construction begins on the Grand Palace, the royal residence of the King of Siam in Bangkok, at the command of King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
Henry Clay introduces the Compromise of 1850 to the U.S. Congress.
Brigham Young declares war on Timpanogos in the Battle at Fort Utah.
The Britannia Bridge across the Menai Strait between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales is opened.
Senator Daniel Webster gives his "Seventh of March" speech endorsing the Compromise of 1850 in order to prevent a possible civil war.
The Arana-Southern Treaty is ratified, ending "the existing differences" between Great Britain and Argentina.
Princess Louise of the Netherlands marries Crown Prince Karl of Sweden-Norway.
Autocephaly officially granted by the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople to the Church of Greece.
U.S. President Zachary Taylor dies after eating raw fruit and iced milk; he is succeeded in office by Vice President Millard Fillmore.
Persian prophet Báb is executed in Tabriz, Persia.
U.S. President Millard Fillmore is sworn in, a day after becoming president upon Zachary Taylor's death.
Ecuador annexes the Galápagos Islands.
In Hiram, Ohio, a group of men beat and tar and feather Mormon leader Joseph Smith.
Black Hawk War: Around 300 United States 6th Infantry troops leave St. Louis, Missouri to fight the Sauk Native Americans.
Greece's independence is recognized by the Treaty of London.
Juan Godoy discovers the rich silver outcrops of Chañarcillo sparking the Chilean silver rush.
The First Kingdom of Greece is declared in the London Conference.
The June Rebellion breaks out in Paris in an attempt to overthrow the monarchy of Louis Philippe.
The June Rebellion in Paris is put down by the National Guard.
The Great Reform Act of England and Wales receives royal assent.
Asian cholera reaches Quebec, brought by Irish immigrants, and kills about 6,000 people in Lower Canada.
Spanish rule ends in Cuba.
The United States takes possession of Wake Island in the Pacific Ocean.
Anglo-Egyptian Sudan is formed.
The Malolos Constitution is inaugurated, establishing the First Philippine Republic. Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as its first president.
The Australian Premiers' Conference held in Melbourne decides to locate Australia's capital city, Canberra, between Sydney and Melbourne.
The Philippine-American War begins with the Battle of Manila.
Spanish-American War: The Treaty of Paris, a peace treaty between the United States and Spain, is ratified by the United States Senate.
Voting machines are approved by the U.S. Congress for use in federal elections.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia issues a declaration known as the February Manifesto, which reduces the autonomy of the Grand Duchy of Finland, thus beginning the first period of oppression.
Iceland's first football club, Knattspyrnufélag Reykjavíkur, is founded.
Ahmad Shah Durrani defeats the Marathas in the Battle of Barari Ghat.
The Great Boston Fire of 1760 destroys 349 buildings.
French forces commence the siege of Quebec which is held by the British.
French forces besieging Quebec retreat after the Royal Navy arrives to relieve the British garrison.
Great Upheaval: New England planters arrive to claim land in Nova Scotia, Canada, taken from the Acadians.
French and Indian War: Robert Rogers and his Rangers surprise French held Fort Sainte Thérèse on the Richelieu River near Lake Champlain. The fort is raided and burned.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Landeshut: Austria defeats Prussia.
Anglo-Cherokee War: Cherokee warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Echoee near present-day Otto, North Carolina.
British forces defeat French forces in the last naval battle in New France.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Liegnitz: Frederick the Great's victory over the Austrians under Ernst Gideon von Laudon.
Establishment of the Colony of Vancouver Island.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: Battle of Chillianwala: British forces retreat from the Sikhs.
Second Anglo-Sikh War: The Siege of Multan ends after nine months when the last Sikh defenders of Multan, Punjab, surrender.
Elizabeth Blackwell is awarded her M.D. by the Geneva Medical College of Geneva, New York, becoming the United States' first female doctor.
University of Wisconsin-Madison's first class meets at Madison Female Academy.
The new Roman Republic is declared.

The delegation headed by Metropolitan bishop Andrei Șaguna hands out to the Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria the General Petition of Romanian leaders in Transylvania, Banat and Bukovina, which demands that the Romanian nation be recognized.
In New York City, James Knox Polk becomes the first serving President of the United States to have his photograph taken.
The Territory of Minnesota is created.

President-elect of the United States Zachary Taylor and Vice President-elect Millard Fillmore did not take their respective oaths of office (they did so the following day), leading to the erroneous theory that outgoing President pro tempore of the United States Senate David Rice Atchison had assumed the role of acting president for one day.
French and Indian War: The Treaty of Paris ends the war and France cedes Quebec to Great Britain.
Berbice slave uprising in Guyana: The first major slave revolt in South America.
Pontiac's War begins with Pontiac's attempt to seize Fort Detroit from the British.
Pontiac's Rebellion: At what is now Mackinaw City, Michigan, Chippewas capture Fort Michilimackinac by diverting the garrison's attention with a game of lacrosse, then chasing a ball into the fort.
Odawa Chief Pontiac's forces defeat British troops at the Battle of Bloody Run during Pontiac's War.
Pontiac's War: Battle of Bushy Run: British forces led by Henry Bouquet defeat Chief Pontiac's Indians at Bushy Run.
Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow.
Seneca warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Devil's Hole during Pontiac's War.
King George III issues the Royal Proclamation of 1763, closing Indigenous lands in North America north and west of the Alleghenies to white settlements.
Dedication of the Touro Synagogue, in Newport, Rhode Island, the first synagogue in what will become the United States.
The first newspaper in Afrikaans, Die Afrikaanse Patriot, is published in Paarl.
The National League of Professional Baseball Clubs of Major League Baseball is formed.
Alexander Graham Bell applies for a patent for the telephone, as does Elisha Gray.
The stage première of Peer Gynt, a play by Henrik Ibsen with incidental music by Edvard Grieg, takes place in Christiania (Oslo), Norway.

Japan and Korea sign the Treaty of Kangwha, which grants Japanese citizens extraterritoriality rights in Korea, opens three Korean ports to Japanese trade, and ends Korea's status as a tributary state of Qing dynasty China.
Alexander Graham Bell is granted a patent for an invention he calls the "telephone".
The first successful test of a telephone is made by Alexander Graham Bell.
The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks is organized.
Catalpa rescue: The rescue of six Fenian prisoners from Fremantle Prison in Western Australia.
The April Uprising begins. Its suppression shocks European opinion, and Bulgarian independence becomes a condition for ending the Russo-Turkish War.
San Agustin Church in Manila is officially completed; it is the oldest church still standing in the Philippines.
An estimated 200 square miles (51,800 ha) along the coasts of the Bristol Channel and Severn Estuary in England are destroyed by massive flooding, resulting in an estimated 2,000 deaths.
L'Orfeo by Claudio Monteverdi, one of the first works recognized as an opera, receives its première performance.
Susenyos I defeats the combined armies of Yaqob and Abuna Petros II at the Battle of Gol in Gojjam, making him Emperor of Ethiopia.
Eighty Years' War: The Dutch fleet destroys the anchored Spanish fleet at Gibraltar.
The Virginia Company colonists make landfall at Cape Henry.
English colonists establish "James Fort," which would become Jamestown, Virginia, the earliest permanent English settlement in the Americas.

One hundred-five English settlers under the leadership of Captain Christopher Newport established the colony called Jamestown at the mouth of the James River on the Virginia coast, the first permanent English colony in America.
Colonists finished building James's Fort, to defend against Spanish and Indian attacks.
The Flight of the Earls takes place in Ireland.
Ramsay MacDonald becomes the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The 1924 Winter Olympics opens in Chamonix, in the French Alps, inaugurating the Winter Olympic Games.
Six days after his death Lenin's body is carried into a specially erected mausoleum.
Russia-United Kingdom relations are restored, over six years after the Communist revolution.
The Royal Greenwich Observatory begins broadcasting the hourly time signals known as the Greenwich Time Signal.
Capital punishment: The first state execution in the United States by gas chamber takes place in Nevada.

George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue received its premiere in a concert titled "An Experiment in Modern Music", in Aeolian Hall, New York, by Paul Whiteman and his band, with Gershwin playing the piano.
The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
The 407-year-old Islamic caliphate is abolished, when Caliph Abdülmecid II of the Ottoman Caliphate is deposed. The last remnant of the old regime gives way to the reformed Turkey of Kemal Atatürk.
The Free State of Fiume is annexed by the Kingdom of Italy.
Fire destroys Jamestown, Virginia.
Emperor Susenyos I of Ethiopia surprises an Oromo army at Ebenat; his army reportedly kills 12,000 Oromo at the cost of 400 of his men.
Susenyos is formally crowned Emperor of Ethiopia.
In Ireland: O'Doherty's Rebellion is launched by the Burning of Derry.
A newly nationalized silver mine in Scotland at Hilderston, West Lothian is re-opened by Bevis Bulmer.
The Protestant Union, a coalition of Protestant German states, is founded to defend the rights, land and safety of each member against the Catholic Church and Catholic German states.
London: Virginia gets new charter, extending borders from "sea to sea".
Samuel de Champlain lands at Tadoussac, Quebec, in the course of his third voyage to New France, and begins erecting fortifications.
Québec City is founded by Samuel de Champlain.
The first official English representative to India lands in Surat.
The Black Friday bushfires burn 20,000 square kilometers of land in Australia, claiming the lives of 71 people.
Norway claims Queen Maud Land in Antarctica.
The deadliest earthquake in Chilean history strikes Chillán, killing approximately 28,000 people.
Spanish Civil War: Catalonia Offensive: Troops loyal to nationalist General Francisco Franco and aided by Italy take Barcelona.
First flight of the Lockheed P-38 Lightning.
Generalísimo Francisco Franco becomes the 68th "Caudillo de España", or Leader of Spain.
Spanish Civil War: The Nationalists conclude their conquest of Catalonia and seal the border with France.

As part of British air raid precautions, the first of 2.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}1⁄2 million Anderson shelters is constructed in a garden in Islington, north London.

United States labor law: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in NLRB v. Fansteel Metallurgical Corp. that the National Labor Relations Board has no authority to force an employer to rehire workers who engage in sit-down strikes.
An Imperial Japanese Army ammunition dump explodes at Hirakata, Osaka, Japan, killing 94.
U.S. President Jimmy Carter authorizes legislation giving $1.5 billion in loans to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.
Iran Air Flight 291 crashes in the Alborz Mountains while on approach to Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran, Iran, killing 128 people.
Mother Teresa is honored with India's highest civilian award, the Bharat Ratna.
Through cooperation between the U.S. and Canadian governments, six American diplomats secretly escape hostilities in Iran in the culmination of the Canadian Caper.
USCGC Blackthorn collides with the tanker Capricorn while leaving Tampa, Florida and capsizes, killing 23 Coast Guard crewmembers.
The Rubik's Cube makes its international debut at the Ideal Toy Corp. in Earl's Court, London.
Reports surface that the FBI is targeting allegedly corrupt Congressmen in the Abscam operation.
First winter ascent of Mount Everest by Krzysztof Wielicki and Leszek Cichy.
Miracle on Ice: In Lake Placid, New York, the United States hockey team defeats the Soviet Union hockey team 4-3.
Iran hostage crisis: Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini states that Iran's parliament will decide the fate of the American embassy hostages.
Northwestern University becomes the first chartered university in Illinois.
The largest Australian bushfires in a populous region in recorded history take place in the state of Victoria.
The first performance of Rigoletto by Giuseppe Verdi takes place in Venice.
Rama IV is crowned King of Thailand after the death of his half-brother, Rama III.
Queen Victoria opens The Great Exhibition at The Crystal Palace in London.
The first Australian gold rush is proclaimed, although the discovery had been made three months earlier.
Slavery in Colombia is abolished.
Harriet Beecher Stowe's anti-slavery serial, Uncle Tom's Cabin, or Life Among the Lowly, starts a ten-month run in the National Era abolitionist newspaper.
Annibale de Gasparis discovers asteroid 15 Eunomia.
Isaac Singer is granted a patent for his sewing machine.

The Convention Parliament convenes to determine whether James II and VII, the last Roman Catholic monarch of England, Ireland and Scotland, had vacated the thrones of England and Ireland when he fled to France in 1688.
The Convention Parliament declares that the flight to France in 1688 by James II, the last Roman Catholic British monarch, constitutes an abdication.
William and Mary are proclaimed co-rulers of England.
James II of England landed at Kinsale, starting the Williamite War in Ireland.
William III and Mary II are crowned as joint sovereigns of Great Britain.
Bostonians rise up in rebellion against Sir Edmund Andros.
Deposed monarch James II of England lays siege to Derry.
The English Parliament passes the Act of Toleration protecting dissenting Protestants but excluding Roman Catholics.
Glorious Revolution: The Battle of Killiecrankie is a victory for the Jacobites.
Beaver Wars: Fifteen hundred Iroquois attack Lachine in New France.
Boshin War: Tokugawa rebels establish the Ezo Republic in Hokkaidō.
The largest alluvial gold nugget in history, called the "Welcome Stranger", is found in Moliagul, Victoria, Australia.
Dmitri Mendeleev presents the first periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society.
The last of Titokowaru's forces surrendered to the New Zealand government, ending his uprising.
Morelos is admitted as the 27th state of Mexico.
Chinese and Irish laborers for the Central Pacific Railroad working on the First Transcontinental Railroad lay ten miles of track in one day, a feat which has never been matched.
The Naval Battle of Hakodate is fought in Japan.
The First Transcontinental Railroad, linking the eastern and western United States, is completed at Promontory Summit, Utah Territory with the golden spike.
Boston University is chartered by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.
The Japanese daimyōs begin returning their land holdings to the emperor as part of the Meiji Restoration reforms. (Traditional Japanese Date: June 17, 1869).
Scotland recognises January 1 as the start of the year, instead of March 25.
On his way to be burned at the stake for heresy, at Campo de' Fiori in Rome, the philosopher Giordano Bruno has a wooden vise put on his tongue to prevent him continuing to speak.
The Peruvian stratovolcano Huaynaputina explodes in the most violent eruption in the recorded history of South America.
The Linköping Bloodbath takes place on Maundy Thursday in Linköping, Sweden: five Swedish noblemen are publicly beheaded in the aftermath of the War against Sigismund (1598-1599).
The Gowrie Conspiracy against King James VI of Scotland (later to become King James I of England) takes place.

Battle of Gifu Castle: The eastern forces of Tokugawa Ieyasu defeat the western Japanese clans loyal to Toyotomi Hideyori, leading to the destruction of Gifu Castle and serving as a prelude to the Battle of Sekigahara.
Euridice, the earliest surviving opera, receives its première performance, beginning the Baroque period.
Tokugawa Ieyasu defeats the leaders of rival Japanese clans in the Battle of Sekigahara and becomes shōgun of Japan.
The British East India Company is chartered.
End of Burmese-Siamese War (1765-67).
Samuel Wallis, a British sea captain, sights Tahiti and is considered the first European to reach the island.
Pitcairn Island is discovered by Midshipman Robert Pitcairn on an expeditionary voyage commanded by Philip Carteret.
Norway's oldest newspaper still in print, Adresseavisen, is founded and the first edition is published.
Jesuits all over Chile are arrested as the Spanish Empire suppresses the Society of Jesus.
Surveying for the Mason-Dixon line separating Maryland from Pennsylvania is completed.
Ahmad Shah Durrani defeats the Marathas in the Battle of Barari Ghat.
The Great Boston Fire of 1760 destroys 349 buildings.
French forces commence the siege of Quebec which is held by the British.
French forces besieging Quebec retreat after the Royal Navy arrives to relieve the British garrison.
Great Upheaval: New England planters arrive to claim land in Nova Scotia, Canada, taken from the Acadians.
French and Indian War: Robert Rogers and his Rangers surprise French held Fort Sainte Thérèse on the Richelieu River near Lake Champlain. The fort is raided and burned.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Landeshut: Austria defeats Prussia.
Anglo-Cherokee War: Cherokee warriors defeat British forces at the Battle of Echoee near present-day Otto, North Carolina.
British forces defeat French forces in the last naval battle in New France.
Seven Years' War: Battle of Liegnitz: Frederick the Great's victory over the Austrians under Ernst Gideon von Laudon.
An Atlantic coast storm sets the lowest confirmed barometric pressure reading for a non-tropical system in the continental United States.

First Balkan War: The Battle of Lemnos begins; Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles, from which it did not venture for the rest of the war.
First Balkan War: A Greek flotilla defeats the Ottoman Navy in the Naval Battle of Lemnos, securing the islands of the Northern Aegean Sea for Greece.
Grand Central Terminal opens in New York City.
The Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, authorizing the Federal government to impose and collect an income tax.
Greek military aviators, Michael Moutoussis and Aristeidis Moraitinis perform the first naval air mission in history, with a Farman MF.7 hydroplane.
A group of meteors is visible across much of the eastern seaboard of the Americas, leading astronomers to conclude the source had been a small, short-lived natural satellite of the Earth.
The 13th Dalai Lama proclaims Tibetan independence following a period of domination by Manchu Qing dynasty and initiated a period of almost four decades of independence.
The Armory Show opens in New York City, displaying works of artists who are to become some of the most influential painters of the early 20th century.
Pedro Lascuráin becomes President of Mexico for 45 minutes; this is the shortest term to date of any person as president of any country.
The first steamboat on the Ohio River or the Mississippi River arrives in New Orleans, 82 days after departing from Pittsburgh.
The strongest in a series of earthquakes strikes New Madrid, Missouri.
Massachusetts governor Elbridge Gerry is accused of "gerrymandering" for the first time.
Argentine War of Independence: Manuel Belgrano raises the Flag of Argentina in the city of Rosario for the first time.
Poet Lord Byron gives his first address as a member of the House of Lords, in defense of Luddite violence against Industrialism in his home county of Nottinghamshire.
The Cortes of Cádiz promulgates the Spanish Constitution of 1812.
An earthquake devastates Caracas, Venezuela.
A political cartoon in the Boston Gazette coins the term "gerrymander" to describe oddly shaped electoral districts designed to help incumbents win reelection.
British forces under the command of the Duke of Wellington assault the fortress of Badajoz. This would be the turning point in the Peninsular War against Napoleon-led France.
Czar Alexander I, the Russian Emperor and the Grand Duke of Finland, officially announces the transfer of the status of the Finnish capital from Turku to Helsinki.
The Southern Nigeria Protectorate is established within the British Empire.

The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton is appointed the first Prime Minister.
The first great Texas oil gusher is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont, Texas.
New York: Automobile Club of America installs signs on major highways.
Queen Victoria, Queen of the United Kingdom, stricken with paralysis. She dies three days later at the age of 81.
Edward VII is proclaimed King of the United Kingdom after the death of his mother, Queen Victoria.
Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters premieres at Moscow Art Theatre in Russia.
Funeral of Queen Victoria.
J. P. Morgan forms U.S. Steel, a $1 billion steel company, having bought some of John D. Rockefeller's iron mines and Andrew Carnegie's entire steel business.
The legislature of Hawaii Territory convenes for the first time.
The Great Fire of Meireki begins in Edo (now Tokyo), Japan, causing more than 100,000 deaths before it exhausts itself three days later.
The Long Parliament presents the Humble Petition and Advice offering Oliver Cromwell the British throne, which he eventually declines.
Admiral Robert Blake destroys a Spanish silver fleet under heavy fire at the Battle of Santa Cruz de Tenerife.
Freedom of religion is granted to the Jews of New Amsterdam (later New York City).
Anglo-Spanish War: Spanish forces fail to retake Jamaica at the Battle of Ocho Rios.
The Flushing Remonstrance articulates for the first time in North American history that freedom of religion is a fundamental right.
Popular Canadian American jockey George Woolf dies in a freak accident during a race; the annual George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award is created to honor him.
The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.

Andrei Zhdanov, Chairman of the Finnish Allied Commission, submitted to the Finnish War Criminal Court an interrogation report by General Erich Buschenhagen, a German prisoner of war, on the contacts between Finnish and German military personnel before the Continuation War and a copy of Hitler's Barbarossa plan.
The first General Assembly of the United Nations assembles in the Methodist Central Hall, Westminster. Fifty-one nations are represented.
The United States Army Signal Corps successfully conducts Project Diana, bouncing radio waves off the Moon and receiving the reflected signals.
Enver Hoxha, Secretary General of the Communist Party of Albania, declares the People's Republic of Albania with himself as head of state.
The UN Security Council holds its first session.
General Douglas MacArthur establishes the International Military Tribunal for the Far East in Tokyo to try Japanese war criminals.

In Iran, Qazi Muhammad declares the independent people's Republic of Mahabad at Chahar Cheragh Square in the Kurdish city of Mahabad; he becomes the new president and Haji Baba Sheikh becomes the prime minister.
Creation of the Central Intelligence Group, forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Mehmed II begins his siege of Constantinople. The city falls on May 29, and is renamed Istanbul.
Three Genoese galleys and a Byzantine blockade runner fight their way through an Ottoman blockading fleet a few weeks before the fall of Constantinople.
Fall of Constantinople: Ottoman armies under Sultan Mehmed II Fatih capture Constantinople after a 53-day siege, ending the Byzantine Empire.
Battle of Castillon: The last battle of Hundred Years' War, the French under Jean Bureau defeat the English under the Earl of Shrewsbury, who is killed in the battle in Gascony.
Hundred Years' War: Three months after the Battle of Castillon, England loses its last possessions in southern France.
Ladislaus the Posthumous is crowned king of Bohemia in Prague.
World War I: The Battle of Gallipoli concludes with an Ottoman Empire victory when the last Allied forces are evacuated from the peninsula.
World War I: Imperial Russia begins the Erzurum Offensive, leading to the defeat of the Ottoman Empire's Third Army.

Both Oswald Boelcke and Max Immelmann, for achieving eight aerial victories each over Allied aircraft, receive the German Empire's highest military award, the Pour le Mérite as the first German aviators to earn it.
In Brushaber v. Union Pacific Railroad Co., the Supreme Court of the United States declares the federal income tax constitutional.
World War I: The British government passes the Military Service Act that introduces conscription in the United Kingdom.

The Canadian province of Manitoba grants women the right to vote and run for office in provincial elections (although still excluding women of Indigenous or Asian heritage), marking the first time women in Canada are granted voting rights.
The Centre Block of the Parliament buildings in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada burns down with the loss of seven lives.
World War I: In France, the Battle of Verdun begins.
The Governor-General of Korea establishes a clinic called Jahyewon in Sorokdo to segregate Hansen's disease patients.
In the Battle of Verdun, a German unit captures Fort Douaumont, keystone of the French defences, without a fight.
Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen of Bohemia after defeating her rival, Charles VII, Holy Roman Emperor.
Jean-Pierre Christin developed the centigrade temperature scale.
In the Battle of Dettingen, George II becomes the last reigning British monarch to participate in a battle.
The Treaty of Åbo ended the 1741-1743 Russo-Swedish War.
The War of the Hats: The Swedish army surrenders to the Russians in Helsinki, ending the war and starting Lesser Wrath.
Great Britain, Austria and the Kingdom of Sardinia sign the Treaty of Worms.
Downtown Disney opens to the public as part of the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
An earthquake hits El Salvador, killing more than 800.
Wikipedia, a free wiki content encyclopedia, goes online.
Second Congo War: Congolese President Laurent-Désiré Kabila is assassinated by one of his own bodyguards in Kinshasa.
US President Bill Clinton awards former President Theodore Roosevelt a posthumous Medal of Honor for his service in the Spanish-American War.
President of the Philippines Joseph Estrada is ousted in a nonviolent four-day revolution, and is succeeded by Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

Five people attempt to set themselves on fire in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, an act that many people later claim is staged by the Communist Party of China to frame Falun Gong and thus escalate their persecution.
The 7.7 Mw Gujarat earthquake shakes Western India, leaving 13,805-20,023 dead and about 166,800 injured.
Thousands of student protesters in Indonesia storm parliament and demand that President Abdurrahman Wahid resign due to alleged involvement in corruption scandals.
In the Netherlands, a Scottish court convicts Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi and acquits another Libyan citizen for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.
Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay becomes a United States federal prison.
A "Law for the Prevention of Genetically Diseased Offspring" comes into effect in Nazi Germany.
The 8.0 Mw  Nepal-Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing an estimated 6,000-10,700 people.
The Apollo Theater reopens in Harlem, New York City.
German-Polish declaration of non-aggression is signed.
The Export-Import Bank of the United States is incorporated.
Far-right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon in an attempted coup against the French Third Republic, creating a political crisis in France.
The Balkan Entente is formed between Greece, Romania, Yugoslavia, and Turkey.
The Austrian Civil War ends with the defeat of the Social Democrats and the Republikanischer Schutzbund.
Augusto Sandino is executed.
Bulgaria and Romania join the EU.
Adam Air Flight 574 breaks apart in mid-air and crashes near the Makassar Strait, Indonesia, killing all 102 people on board.
The 110th United States Congress convenes, electing Nancy Pelosi as the first female Speaker of the House in U.S. history.
Apple CEO Steve Jobs introduces the original iPhone at a Macworld keynote in San Francisco.
A general strike begins in Guinea in an attempt to get President Lansana Conté to resign.
Comet C/2006 P1 (McNaught), one of the brightest comets ever observed is at its zenith visible during the day.
The Doomsday Clock is set to five minutes to midnight in response to North Korea's nuclear testing.

The strongest storm in the United Kingdom in 17 years kills 14 people and Germany sees the worst storm since 1999 with 13 deaths. Cyclone Kyrill causes at least 44 deaths across 20 countries in Western Europe.
Turkish-Armenian journalist Hrant Dink is assassinated in front of his newspaper's Istanbul office by 17-year-old Turkish ultra-nationalist Ogün Samast.

Four-man Team N2i, using only skis and kites, completes a 1,093-mile (1,759 km) trek to reach the Antarctic pole of inaccessibility for the first time since 1965 and for the first time ever without mechanical assistance.
